   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Turkey
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
     Jump to:
     <a href="#mw-head">
      navigation
     </a>

     </a>

     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       This article is about the country. For the bird, see
       <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(bird)" title="Turkey (bird)">
        Turkey (bird)
       </a>
       . For other uses, see
       <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Turkey_(disambiguation)" title="Turkey (disambiguation)">
        Turkey (disambiguation)
       </a>
       .
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       "Türkiye" redirects here. For the newspaper, see
       <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_(newspaper)" title="Türkiye (newspaper)">
        Türkiye (newspaper)
       </a>
       .
      </div>

            <a href="/wiki/Kabardian_language" title="Kabardian language">
             Kabardian
            </a>
           </li>
           <li>
            <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Turkey" title="Languages of Turkey">
             various others
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>

          .tr
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="line-height:11pt">
          <b>
           Website
          </b>
          <br/>
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.turkiye.gov.tr/" rel="nofollow">
           www.turkiye.gov.tr
          </a>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <b>
        Turkey
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'t' in 'tie'">
            t
           </span>
           <span title="/ɜːr/: 'ur' in 'fur'">
            ɜːr
           </span>
           <span title="'k' in 'kind'">
            k
           </span>
           <span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">
            i
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Turkey.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/89/En-us-Turkey.ogg" title="En-us-Turkey.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
        Turkish
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="tr">
         Türkiye
        </span>
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Oghuz_languages" title="Help:IPA/Oghuz languages">
         [ˈtyɾcije]
        </a>
       </span>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Turkey
       </b>
       (Turkish:
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/37/Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg" title="Tur-Türkiye Cumhuriyeti.ogg">
          <i>
           Türkiye Cumhuriyeti
          </i>
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">
         (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           help
          </span>
         </a>
         ·
         <a href="/wiki/File:Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg" title="File:Tur-Türkiye Cumhuriyeti.ogg">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           info
          </span>
         </a>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ;
       <small>
        pronounced
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Oghuz_languages" title="Help:IPA/Oghuz languages">
         [ˈtyɾcije d͡ʒumˈhuɾijeti]
        </a>
       </span>
       ), is a
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries" title="List of transcontinental countries">
        transcontinental
       </a>
       country in
       <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">
        Eurasia
       </a>
       , mainly in
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
        Anatolia
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">
        Western Asia
       </a>
       , with a
       <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">
        smaller portion
       </a>
       on the
       <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
        Balkan peninsula
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">
        Southeast Europe
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-9">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey is bordered by eight countries with
       <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">
        Greece
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">
        Bulgaria
       </a>
       to the northwest;
       <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">
        Georgia
       </a>
       to the northeast;
       <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">
        Armenia
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">
        Azerbaijani
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exclave" title="Exclave">
        exclave
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Nakhchivan_Autonomous_Republic" title="Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic">
        Nakhchivan
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">
        Iran
       </a>
       to the east; and
       <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">
        Iraq
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">
        Syria
       </a>
       to the south. The country is encircled by seas on three sides with the
       <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">
        Aegean Sea
       </a>
       to the west, the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
        Black Sea
       </a>
       to the north, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
        Mediterranean Sea
       </a>
       to the south. The
       <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">
        Bosphorus
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">
        Sea of Marmara
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">
        Dardanelles
       </a>
       , which together form the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Straits" title="Turkish Straits">
        Turkish Straits
       </a>
       , divide
       <a href="/wiki/Thrace" title="Thrace">
        Thrace
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
        Anatolia
       </a>
       and separate Europe and Asia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NatlGeoAtlas2_10-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NatlGeoAtlas2-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">
        Ankara
       </a>
       is the capital while
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
        Istanbul
       </a>
       is the country's largest city and main cultural and commercial centre. Approximately 70-80% of the country's citizens identify themselves as ethnic
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">
        Turks
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-konda2_11-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-konda2-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia2_12-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cia2-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Kurds are the largest minority at about 20% of the population, and other ethnic minorities include
       <a href="/wiki/Circassians_in_Turkey" title="Circassians in Turkey">
        Circassians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Albanians_in_Turkey" title="Albanians in Turkey">
        Albanians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">
        Arabs
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks_in_Turkey" title="Bosniaks in Turkey">
        Bosniaks
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Laz_people" title="Laz people">
        Laz
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia2_12-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cia2-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roopnarine2015_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Roopnarine2015-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MedinaHepner2013_14-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MedinaHepner2013-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Minority languages spoken today in Turkey include
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Kurdish" title="Northern Kurdish">
        Kurmanji
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">
        Arabic
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zaza_language" title="Zaza language">
        Zaza
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kabardian_language" title="Kabardian language">
        Kabardian
       </a>
       and several others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnologue_1-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue-1">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The area of Turkey has been inhabited since the
       <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">
        Paleolithic
       </a>
       age by various
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Anatolians" title="Ancient Anatolians">
        ancient Anatolian civilisations
       </a>
       , as well as
       <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_people" title="Assyrian people">
        Assyrians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">
        Greeks
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">
        Thracians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Phrygians" title="Phrygians">
        Phrygians
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urartians" title="Urartians">
        Urartians
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">
        Armenians
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Howard2_18-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Howard2-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_19-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MET2_20-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MET2-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">
        Alexander the Great
       </a>
       conquered these lands, the area was
       <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">
        Hellenized
       </a>
       , a process which continued under the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       and its transition into the
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine Empire
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_19-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FreedmanMyers20002_21-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FreedmanMyers20002-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuk_Turks" title="Seljuk Turks">
        Seljuk Turks
       </a>
       began migrating into the area in the 11th century, and their victory over the Byzantines at the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert" title="Battle of Manzikert">
        Battle of Manzikert
       </a>
       in 1071 symbolizes the start of
       <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">
        Turkification
       </a>
       in Anatolia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_R%C3%BBm" title="Sultanate of Rûm">
        Seljuk Sultanate of Rûm
       </a>
       ruled Anatolia until the
       <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Anatolia" title="Mongol invasions of Anatolia">
        Mongol invasion
       </a>
       in 1243, when it disintegrated into small
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">
        Turkish beyliks
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mfk&amp;gl2_23-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mfk&amp;gl2-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From the end of the 13th century the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_dynasty" title="Ottoman dynasty">
        Ottomans
       </a>
       started uniting Turkish principalities in Anatolia and then went on to create an empire that encompassed much of Southeast Europe, West Asia and
       <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">
        North Africa
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       became a world power beginning with the reign of
       <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">
        Suleiman the Magnificent
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Early_modern_period" title="Early modern period">
        early modern period
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It remained powerful and influential for two more centuries, until important setbacks in the 18th and 19th century forced it to cede strategic territories in Europe, which signalled the loss of its former military strength and wealth. After the
       <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d'état">
        1913 Ottoman coup d'état
       </a>
       , which effectively put the country under the control of the
       <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">
        Three Pashas
       </a>
       , the Ottoman Empire
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_entry_into_World_War_I" title="Ottoman entry into World War I">
        decided to join
       </a>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">
        Central Powers
       </a>
       during
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       . During the war, the Ottoman government committed
       <a href="/wiki/Genocides_in_history#Ottoman_Empire" title="Genocides in history">
        genocides
       </a>
       against its
       <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" title="Armenian Genocide">
        Armenian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" title="Assyrian genocide">
        Assyrian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">
        Pontic Greek
       </a>
       subjects.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-two_26-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-two-26">
         [I]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SchallerZimmerer_27-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SchallerZimmerer-27">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Following the war, the conglomeration of territories and peoples that formerly comprised the Ottoman Empire was
       <a href="/wiki/Partition_(politics)" title="Partition (politics)">
        partitioned
       </a>
       into
       <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Partition of the Ottoman Empire">
        several new states
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">
        Turkish War of Independence
       </a>
       , initiated by
       <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">
        Mustafa Kemal Atatürk
       </a>
       and his colleagues against occupying
       <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">
        Allies
       </a>
       , resulted in the
       <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Ottoman_sultanate" title="Abolition of the Ottoman sultanate">
        abolition of monarchy
       </a>
       in 1922 and the establishment of the Republic of Turkey in 1923, with Atatürk as its first president.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica_29-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Britannica-29">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Atatürk enacted
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_reforms" title="Atatürk's reforms">
        numerous reforms
       </a>
       , many of which incorporated various aspects of
       <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">
        western
       </a>
       thought, philosophy, and customs into the new form of Turkish government.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Turkey is a charter member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        UN
       </a>
       , an early member of
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">
        IMF
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">
        World Bank
       </a>
       , and a founding member of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organization_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">
        OSCE
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">
        BSEC
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">
        OIC
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">
        G-20
       </a>
       . After becoming
       <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">
        one of the first members
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       in 1949, Turkey became an
       <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">
        associate member
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">
        EEC
       </a>
       in 1963, joined the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">
        EU Customs Union
       </a>
       in 1995 and started
       <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">
        accession negotiations
       </a>
       with the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       in 2005 which have been effectively stopped by the EU in 2017 due to "Turkey’s path toward autocratic rule".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-31">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey's economy and diplomatic initiatives led to its recognition as a
       <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">
        regional power
       </a>
       while its location has given it geopolitical and strategic importance throughout history.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-giga-hamburg.de1_32-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-giga-hamburg.de1-32">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isanet.org1_33-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-isanet.org1-33">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Turkey's current administration headed by president
       <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">
        Tayyip Erdoğan
       </a>
       has reversed many of the earlier reforms, such as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_Press" title="Freedom of the Press">
        Freedom of the Press
       </a>
       , a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Checks_and_balances" title="Checks and balances">
        Legislative System of Checks and Balances
       </a>
       , and a set of standards for secularism in government, as previously enacted by Atatürk.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey is a
       <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">
        secular
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">
        parliamentary republic
       </a>
       ; slated to transition to a presidential system in 2019, following a
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_constitutional_referendum,_2017" title="Turkish constitutional referendum, 2017">
        2017 referendum
       </a>
       . However, Turkey's current administration headed by president Tayyip Erdoğan of the AKP has enacted measures to increase the influence of
       <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
        Islam
       </a>
       , reversed and undermined secularist policies, and has reversed earlier reforms such as freedom of the press.
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>
      <div class="toc" id="toc">
       <div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en">

        </li>

         </a>

            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-12">

           </a>
          </li>

        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-14">

          </span>

          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-15">

          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-17">
         <a href="#Economy">
          <span class="tocnumber">

          </span>
          <span class="toctext">

          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-18">
           <a href="#History_2">
            <span class="tocnumber">

            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             History
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-19">
           <a href="#Tourism">
            <span class="tocnumber">

            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Tourism
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20">
           <a href="#Infrastructure">
            <span class="tocnumber">

            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Infrastructure
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-21">
           <a href="#Science_and_technology">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             6.4
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Science and technology
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-22">
         <a href="#Demographics">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           7
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Demographics
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-23">
           <a href="#Languages">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.1
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Languages
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-24">
           <a href="#Religion">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.2
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Religion
            </span>
           </a>
           <ul>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-25">
             <a href="#Islam">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               7.2.1
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">
               Islam
              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-26">
             <a href="#Christianity">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               7.2.2
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">
               Christianity
              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-27">
             <a href="#Judaism">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               7.2.3
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">
               Judaism
              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-28">
             <a href="#Agnosticism_and_atheism">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               7.2.4
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">
               Agnosticism and atheism
              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-29">
           <a href="#Education">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             7.3
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Education
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>

        </li>

      </div>
      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Turkey" title="Name of Turkey">
        Name of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The name of Turkey (
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
        Turkish
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        Türkiye
       </i>
       ) can be divided into two components: the
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">
        ethnonym
       </a>
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">
         Türk
        </a>
       </i>
       and the abstract
       <a href="/wiki/Suffix" title="Suffix">
        suffix
       </a>
       <i>
        –iye
       </i>
       meaning "owner", "land of" or "related to" (originally derived from the
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">
        Greek
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">
        Latin
       </a>
       suffixes
       <i>
        –ia
       </i>
       in
       <i>
        Tourkia
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        Τουρκία
       </i>
       ) and
       <i>
        Turchia
       </i>
       ). The first recorded use of the term "Türk" or "Türük" as an
       <a href="/wiki/Exonym_and_endonym" title="Exonym and endonym">
        autonym
       </a>
       is contained in the
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Turkic_alphabet" title="Old Turkic alphabet">
        Old Turkic
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Orkhon_inscriptions" title="Orkhon inscriptions">
        inscriptions
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrks" title="Göktürks">
        Göktürks
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Celestial Turks
       </i>
       ) of Central Asia (c. AD 735).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">
        Turkic
       </a>
       self-designation
       <i>
        Türk
       </i>
       is first attested in reference to the
       <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrks" title="Göktürks">
        Göktürks
       </a>
       in the 6th century AD. A letter by
       <a href="/wiki/Ishbara_Qaghan" title="Ishbara Qaghan">
        Ishbara Qaghan
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Wen_of_Sui" title="Emperor Wen of Sui">
        Emperor Wen of Sui
       </a>
       in 585 described him as "the Great Turk Khan."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       An early form of the same name may be reflected in the form of
       <i>
        "tie-le"
       </i>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Tiele_people" title="Tiele people">
        鐵勒
       </a>
       ) or
       <i>
        "tu-jue"
       </i>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tujue" title="Tujue">
        突厥
       </a>
       ), name given by the
       <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people" title="Chinese people">
        Chinese
       </a>
       to the people living south of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Altay_Mountains" title="Altay Mountains">
        Altay Mountains
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">
        Central Asia
       </a>
       as early as 177 BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TurkEtymology2_41-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TurkEtymology2-41">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Greek name,
       <i>
        Tourkia
       </i>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">
        Greek
       </a>
       :
       <span lang="el">
        Τουρκία
       </span>
       ) was used by the
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Byzantine_emperors" title="List of Byzantine emperors">
        emperor and scholar
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_VII_Porphyrogenitus" title="Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus">
        Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus
       </a>
       in his book
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/De_Administrando_Imperio" title="De Administrando Imperio">
         De Administrando Imperio
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PrinzingSalamon19992_43-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PrinzingSalamon19992-43">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       though in his use, "Turks" always referred to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magyars" title="Magyars">
        Magyars
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Howorth20082_44-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Howorth20082-44">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Similarly, the medieval
       <a href="/wiki/Khazars" title="Khazars">
        Khazar Empire
       </a>
       , a Turkic state on the northern shores of the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
        Black
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">
        Caspian
       </a>
       seas, was referred to as
       <i>
        Tourkia
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        Land of the Turks
       </i>
       ) in Byzantine sources.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, the Byzantines later began using this name to define the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Seljuk_Empire" title="Great Seljuk Empire">
        Seljuk
       </a>
       -controlled
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatolian_Seljuk_Sultanate" title="Anatolian Seljuk Sultanate">
        parts of Anatolia
       </a>
       in the centuries that followed the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert" title="Battle of Manzikert">
        Battle of Manzikert
       </a>
       in 1071. The medieval Greek and Latin terms did not designate the same geographic area now known as Turkey. Instead, they were mostly synonymous with
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Tartary" title="Tartary">
         Tartary
        </a>
       </i>
       , a term including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khazaria" title="Khazaria">
        Khazaria
       </a>
       and the other khaganates of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Asian" title="Central Asian">
        Central Asian
       </a>
       steppe, until the appearance of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuks" title="Seljuks">
        Seljuks
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of the Ottoman Empire">
        rise of the Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       in the 14th century, reflecting the progress of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkic_expansion" title="Turkic expansion">
        Turkic expansion
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Turkey" title="History of Turkey">
        History of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Anatolia" title="History of Anatolia">
        History of Anatolia
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Thrace" title="History of Thrace">
        History of Thrace
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_of_Anatolia_and_Eastern_Thrace">
        Prehistory of Anatolia and Eastern Thrace
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Anatolia" title="Prehistory of Anatolia">
        Prehistory of Anatolia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Southeastern_Europe" title="Prehistory of Southeastern Europe">
        Prehistory of Southeastern Europe
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Anatolians" title="Ancient Anatolians">
        Ancient Anatolians
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_kingdoms_of_Anatolia" title="Ancient kingdoms of Anatolia">
        Ancient kingdoms of Anatolia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">
        Thracians
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe,_Urfa.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/220px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/330px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/440px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe,_Urfa.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Some
         <a href="/wiki/Henge" title="Henge">
          henges
         </a>
         at
         <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">
          Göbekli Tepe
         </a>
         were erected as far back as
         <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe#Layer_III" title="Göbekli Tepe">
          9600 BC
         </a>
         , predating those of
         <a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">
          Stonehenge
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">
          England
         </a>
         , by over seven millennia.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArchMag_46-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-ArchMag-46">
           [45]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lion_Gate,_Hattusa_01.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Lion_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/220px-Lion_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Lion_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/330px-Lion_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Lion_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/440px-Lion_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lion_Gate,_Hattusa_01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Lion Gate in
         <a href="/wiki/Hattusa" title="Hattusa">
          Hattusa
         </a>
         , capital of the
         <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">
          Hittite Empire
         </a>
         . The city's history dates back to the 6th millennium BC.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whcunesco_47-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-whcunesco-47">
           [46]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Anatolian peninsula, comprising most of modern Turkey, is one of the oldest permanently settled regions in the world. Various
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Anatolians" title="Ancient Anatolians">
        ancient Anatolian
       </a>
       populations have lived in
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
        Anatolia
       </a>
       , from at least the
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
        Neolithic
       </a>
       period until the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" title="Hellenistic civilization">
        Hellenistic period
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon2011_48-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon2011-48">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many of these peoples spoke the
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_languages" title="Anatolian languages">
        Anatolian languages
       </a>
       , a branch of the larger
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-European_language_family" title="Indo-European language family">
        Indo-European language family
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UCLA_49-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UCLA-49">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In fact, given the antiquity of the Indo-European
       <a href="/wiki/Hittite_language" title="Hittite language">
        Hittite
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Luwian_language" title="Luwian language">
        Luwian
       </a>
       languages, some scholars have proposed Anatolia as the hypothetical centre from which the Indo-European languages radiated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnatoliaIndoEuropean_50-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AnatoliaIndoEuropean-50">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The European part of Turkey, called
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Thrace" title="Eastern Thrace">
        Eastern Thrace
       </a>
       , has also been inhabited since at least forty thousand years ago, and is known to have been in the
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
        Neolithic
       </a>
       era by about 6000 BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MET_51-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MET-51">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="Göbekli Tepe">
        Göbekli Tepe
       </a>
       is the site of the oldest known man-made religious structure, a temple dating to circa 10,000 BC,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArchMag_46-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ArchMag-46">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%87atalh%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="Çatalhöyük">
        Çatalhöyük
       </a>
       is a very large Neolithic and
       <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">
        Chalcolithic
       </a>
       settlement in southern Anatolia, which existed from approximately 7500 BC to 5700 BC. It is the largest and best-preserved Neolithic site found to date and in July 2012 was inscribed as a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">
        UNESCO World Heritage Site
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The settlement of
       <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">
        Troy
       </a>
       started in the Neolithic Age and continued into the
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
        Iron Age
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The earliest recorded inhabitants of Anatolia were the
       <a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">
        Hattians
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hurrians" title="Hurrians">
        Hurrians
       </a>
       , non-Indo-European peoples who inhabited central and eastern Anatolia, respectively, as early as ca. 2300 BC. Indo-European
       <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">
        Hittites
       </a>
       came to Anatolia and gradually absorbed the Hattians and Hurrians ca. 2000–1700 BC. The first major empire in the area was founded by the Hittites, from the 18th through the 13th century BC. The
       <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">
        Assyrians
       </a>
       conquered and settled parts of southeastern Turkey as early as 1950 BC until the year 612 BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">
        Urartu
       </a>
       re-emerged in Assyrian inscriptions in the 9th century BC as a powerful northern rival of Assyria.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
        <a href="#cite_note-56">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Following the collapse of the Hittite empire c. 1180 BC, the
       <a href="/wiki/Phrygia" title="Phrygia">
        Phrygians
       </a>
       , an Indo-European people, achieved ascendancy in Anatolia until their kingdom was destroyed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Cimmerians" title="Cimmerians">
        Cimmerians
       </a>
       in the 7th century BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TroyHittiteEmpirePhrygians_57-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TroyHittiteEmpirePhrygians-57">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Starting from 714 BC, Urartu shared the same fate and dissolved in 590 BC,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       when it was conquered by the
       <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">
        Medes
       </a>
       . The most powerful of Phrygia's successor states were
       <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">
        Lydia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Caria" title="Caria">
        Caria
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Lycia" title="Lycia">
        Lycia
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:519px;max-width:519px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:273px;max-width:273px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Bath-Gymnasium_complex_at_Sardis,_late_2nd_-_early_3rd_century_AD,_Sardis,_Turkey_(17098680002).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3252" data-file-width="4903" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/The_Bath-Gymnasium_complex_at_Sardis%2C_late_2nd_-_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Sardis%2C_Turkey_%2817098680002%29.jpg/271px-The_Bath-Gymnasium_complex_at_Sardis%2C_late_2nd_-_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Sardis%2C_Turkey_%2817098680002%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/The_Bath-Gymnasium_complex_at_Sardis%2C_late_2nd_-_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Sardis%2C_Turkey_%2817098680002%29.jpg/407px-The_Bath-Gymnasium_complex_at_Sardis%2C_late_2nd_-_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Sardis%2C_Turkey_%2817098680002%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/The_Bath-Gymnasium_complex_at_Sardis%2C_late_2nd_-_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Sardis%2C_Turkey_%2817098680002%29.jpg/542px-The_Bath-Gymnasium_complex_at_Sardis%2C_late_2nd_-_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Sardis%2C_Turkey_%2817098680002%29.jpg 2x" width="271"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          The
          <a href="/wiki/Gymnasium_(ancient_Greece)" title="Gymnasium (ancient Greece)">
           gymnasium
          </a>
          of
          <a href="/wiki/Sardis" title="Sardis">
           Sardis
          </a>
          , capital of ancient
          <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">
           Lydia
          </a>
          (c. 1200 BC–546 BC), the successor state of ancient
          <a href="/wiki/Arzawa" title="Arzawa">
           Arzawa
          </a>
          (15th–13th centuries BC).
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rhodes_59-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-rhodes-59">
            [58]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:242px;max-width:242px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Walls_of_Troy_(2).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1167" data-file-width="1556" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Walls_of_Troy_%282%29.jpg/240px-Walls_of_Troy_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Walls_of_Troy_%282%29.jpg/360px-Walls_of_Troy_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Walls_of_Troy_%282%29.jpg/480px-Walls_of_Troy_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="240"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Walls of the
          <a href="/wiki/Acropolis" title="Acropolis">
           acropolis
          </a>
          of
          <a href="/wiki/Troy#Troy_VI_and_VII" title="Troy">
           Troy VIIa
          </a>
          , the site of the
          <a href="/wiki/Trojan_War" title="Trojan War">
           Trojan War
          </a>
          (c. 1200 BC) that inspired
          <a href="/wiki/Homer" title="Homer">
           Homer
          </a>
          's
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Iliad" title="Iliad">
            Iliad
           </a>
          </i>
          .
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
           <a href="#cite_note-60">
            [59]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">
        Antiquity
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">
        Classical Anatolia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7100" data-file-width="9163" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/220px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/330px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/440px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Celsus" title="Library of Celsus">
          Library of Celsus
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">
          Ephesus
         </a>
         was built by the
         <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
          Romans
         </a>
         in 114–117 AD.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
          <a href="#cite_note-61">
           [60]
          </a>
         </sup>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Artemis" title="Temple of Artemis">
          Temple of Artemis
         </a>
         in Ephesus, built by king
         <a href="/wiki/Croesus" title="Croesus">
          Croesus
         </a>
         of
         <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">
          Lydia
         </a>
         in the 6th century BC, was one of the
         <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">
          Seven Wonders of the Ancient World
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
          <a href="#cite_note-62">
           [61]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Starting around 1200 BC, the coast of
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
        Anatolia
       </a>
       was heavily settled by
       <a href="/wiki/Aeolians" title="Aeolians">
        Aeolian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ionians" title="Ionians">
        Ionian
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">
        Greeks
       </a>
       . Numerous important cities were founded by these colonists, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Miletus" title="Miletus">
        Miletus
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">
        Ephesus
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">
        Smyrna
       </a>
       (now
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0zmir" title="İzmir">
        İzmir
       </a>
       ) and
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">
        Byzantium
       </a>
       (now
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
        Istanbul
       </a>
       ), the latter founded by
       <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">
        Greek
       </a>
       colonists from
       <a href="/wiki/Megara" title="Megara">
        Megara
       </a>
       in 657 BC. The first state that was called
       <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">
        Armenia
       </a>
       by neighbouring peoples was the state of the
       <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">
        Armenian
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orontid_dynasty" title="Orontid dynasty">
        Orontid dynasty
       </a>
       , which included parts of eastern Turkey beginning in the 6th century BC. In Northwest Turkey, the most significant tribal group in Thrace was the
       <a href="/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom" title="Odrysian kingdom">
        Odyrisians
       </a>
       , founded by
       <a href="/wiki/Teres_I" title="Teres I">
        Teres I
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LewisBoardman1994_63-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LewisBoardman1994-63">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       All of modern-day Turkey was conquered by the Persian
       <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">
        Achaemenid Empire
       </a>
       during the 6th century BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_companion_to_Ancient_Macedonia_64-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-A_companion_to_Ancient_Macedonia-64">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">
        Greco-Persian Wars
       </a>
       started when the Greek city states on the coast of Anatolia rebelled against Persian rule in 499 BC. The territory of Turkey later fell to
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">
        Alexander the Great
       </a>
       in 334 BC,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PersiansInAsiaMinor_65-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PersiansInAsiaMinor-65">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which led to increasing cultural homogeneity and
       <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">
        Hellenization
       </a>
       in the area.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon2011_48-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon2011-48">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Following Alexander's death in 323 BC, Anatolia was subsequently divided into a number of small
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" title="Hellenistic civilization">
        Hellenistic kingdoms
       </a>
       , all of which became part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">
        Roman Republic
       </a>
       by the mid-1st century BC.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlexanderToRome_66-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AlexanderToRome-66">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The process of
       <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">
        Hellenization
       </a>
       that began with Alexander's conquest accelerated under Roman rule, and by the early centuries of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Era" title="Christian Era">
        Christian Era
       </a>
       , the local
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_languages" title="Anatolian languages">
        Anatolian languages
       </a>
       and cultures had become extinct, being largely replaced by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language" title="Ancient Greek language">
        ancient Greek language
       </a>
       and culture.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FreedmanMyers2000_67-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FreedmanMyers2000-67">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hout2011_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hout2011-68">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       From the 1st century BC up to the 3rd century CE, large parts of modern-day Turkey were contested between the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Romans
       </a>
       and neighbouring
       <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">
        Parthians
       </a>
       through the frequent
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman-Parthian_Wars" title="Roman-Parthian Wars">
        Roman-Parthian Wars
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Christian_and_Byzantine_period">
        Early Christian and Byzantine period
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Anatolia" title="Byzantine Anatolia">
        Byzantine Anatolia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">
        Hellenistic period
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine Empire
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Successors_of_the_Byzantine_Empire" title="Successors of the Byzantine Empire">
        Successors of the Byzantine Empire
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/States_in_late_medieval_Anatolia" title="States in late medieval Anatolia">
        States in late medieval Anatolia
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_(2216460729).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2534" data-file-width="3329" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/220px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/330px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/440px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_(2216460729).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Originally a church, later a mosque, and now a museum, the
         <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">
          Hagia Sophia
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
          Istanbul
         </a>
         was built by the
         <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
          Byzantine
         </a>
         emperor
         <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">
          Justinian I
         </a>
         in 532–537 AD.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
          <a href="#cite_note-69">
           [68]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 324,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_I" title="Constantine I">
        Constantine I
       </a>
       chose
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">
        Byzantium
       </a>
       to be the new capital of the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       , renaming it
       <a href="/wiki/New_Rome" title="New Rome">
        New Rome
       </a>
       . Following the death of
       <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">
        Theodosius I
       </a>
       in 395 and the permanent division of the Roman Empire between his two sons, the city, which would popularly come to be known as
       <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">
        Constantinople
       </a>
       , became the capital of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" title="Eastern Roman Empire">
        Eastern Roman Empire
       </a>
       . This empire, which would later be branded by historians as the
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine Empire
       </a>
       , ruled most of the territory of present-day Turkey until the
       <a href="/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages" title="Late Middle Ages">
        Late Middle Ages
       </a>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       although the eastern regions remained in firm
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sasanian" title="Sasanian">
        Sasanian
       </a>
       hands up to the first half of the seventh century. The frequent
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine-Sassanid_Wars" title="Byzantine-Sassanid Wars">
        Byzantine-Sassanid Wars
       </a>
       , as part of the centuries long-lasting
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman-Persian_Wars" title="Roman-Persian Wars">
        Roman-Persian Wars
       </a>
       , fought between the neighbouring rivalling Byzantines and Sasanians, took place in various parts of present-day Turkey and decided much of the latter's history from the fourth century up to the first half of the seventh century.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:528px;max-width:528px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:262px;max-width:262px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2832" data-file-width="4256" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg/260px-Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg/390px-Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg/520px-Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg 2x" width="260"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          Designed by Greek architect Zeno, a native of the city, the
          <a href="/wiki/Aspendos" title="Aspendos">
           Aspendos
          </a>
          amphitheatre was built during the Roman period in 161–169 CE.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
           <a href="#cite_note-71">
            [70]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:262px;max-width:262px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:East_Terrace_(4961356591).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3154" data-file-width="4727" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/East_Terrace_%284961356591%29.jpg/260px-East_Terrace_%284961356591%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/East_Terrace_%284961356591%29.jpg/390px-East_Terrace_%284961356591%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/East_Terrace_%284961356591%29.jpg/520px-East_Terrace_%284961356591%29.jpg 2x" width="260"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Mount_Nemrut" title="Mount Nemrut">
           Mount Nemrut
          </a>
          , built by the Armenian
          <a href="/wiki/Antiochus_I_Theos_of_Commagene" title="Antiochus I Theos of Commagene">
           Antiochus I Theos of Commagene
          </a>
          , is notable for its summit where a number of large statues are erected around what is assumed to be a royal tomb from the 1st century BC.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whc.unesco.orgx_72-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-whc.unesco.orgx-72">
            [71]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Seljuks_and_the_Ottoman_Empire">
        Seljuks and the Ottoman Empire
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuk_dynasty" title="Seljuk dynasty">
        Seljuk dynasty
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_dynasty" title="Ottoman dynasty">
        Ottoman dynasty
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">
        Turkic migration
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Anatolia" title="Mongol invasions of Anatolia">
        Mongol invasions of Anatolia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">
        Seljuk Empire
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">
        Sultanate of Rum
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2595" data-file-width="3529" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg/220px-Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg/330px-Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg/440px-Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mausoleo_Mevlana.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mevlana_Museum" title="Mevlana Museum">
          Mevlana Museum
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">
          Konya
         </a>
         was built by the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuks" title="Seljuks">
          Seljuk Turks
         </a>
         in 1274. Konya was the capital of the Seljuk
         <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">
          Sultanate of Rum
         </a>
         (Anatolia).
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turktarihim.com_73-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-turktarihim.com-73">
           [72]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Seljuq_dynasty" title="Seljuq dynasty">
        House of Seljuk
       </a>
       was a branch of the
       <i>
        Kınık
       </i>
       <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Turks" title="Oghuz Turks">
        Oğuz Turks
       </a>
       who resided on the periphery of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href='/wiki/Muslim_history#Abbasids_-_"Islamic_Golden_Age"' title="Muslim history">
        Muslim world
       </a>
       , in the
       <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Yabgu_State" title="Oghuz Yabgu State">
        Yabgu Khaganate
       </a>
       of the Oğuz confederacy, to the north of the
       <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">
        Caspian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Aral_Sea" title="Aral Sea">
        Aral Seas
       </a>
       , in the 9th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the 10th century, the Seljuks started migrating from their ancestral homeland into
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persia" title="Persia">
        Persia
       </a>
       , which became the administrative core of the
       <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">
        Great Seljuk Empire
       </a>
       , after its foundation by
       <a href="/wiki/Tughril" title="Tughril">
        Tughril
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-peter.mackenzie.org_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-peter.mackenzie.org-75">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the latter half of the 11th century, the Seljuk Turks began penetrating into
       <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Armenia" title="Medieval Armenia">
        medieval Armenia
       </a>
       and the eastern regions of
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
        Anatolia
       </a>
       . In 1071, the Seljuks defeated the Byzantines at the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert" title="Battle of Manzikert">
        Battle of Manzikert
       </a>
       , starting the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">
        Turkification
       </a>
       process in the area; the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
        Turkish language
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
        Islam
       </a>
       were introduced to Armenia and Anatolia, gradually spreading throughout the region. The slow transition from a predominantly
       <a href="/wiki/Christian" title="Christian">
        Christian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">
        Greek
       </a>
       -speaking Anatolia to a predominantly
       <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">
        Muslim
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
        Turkish
       </a>
       -speaking one was underway. The
       <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">
        Mevlevi Order
       </a>
       of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dervishes" title="Dervishes">
        dervishes
       </a>
       , which was established in
       <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">
        Konya
       </a>
       during the 13th century by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sufi" title="Sufi">
        Sufi
       </a>
       poet
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celaleddin_Rumi" title="Celaleddin Rumi">
        Celaleddin Rumi
       </a>
       , played a significant role in the
       <a href="/wiki/Islamization" title="Islamization">
        Islamization
       </a>
       of the diverse people of Anatolia who had previously been
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenized" title="Hellenized">
        Hellenized
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Thus, alongside the Turkification of the territory, the
       <a href="/wiki/Persianate_society" title="Persianate society">
        culturally Persianized
       </a>
       Seljuks set the basis for a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turko-Persian_tradition" title="Turko-Persian tradition">
        Turko-Persian principal culture
       </a>
       in Anatolia,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which their eventual successors,
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Culture of the Ottoman Empire">
        the Ottomans
       </a>
       , would take over.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1243, the Seljuk armies were defeated by the
       <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">
        Mongols
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_K%C3%B6se_Da%C4%9F" title="Battle of Köse Dağ">
        Battle of Köse Dağ
       </a>
       , causing the Seljuk Empire's power to slowly disintegrate. In its wake, one of the
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">
        Turkish principalities
       </a>
       governed by
       <a href="/wiki/Osman_I" title="Osman I">
        Osman I
       </a>
       would evolve over the next 200 years into the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       . In 1453, the Ottomans completed their conquest of the
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine Empire
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">
        capturing its capital
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">
        Constantinople
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ottomans_81-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ottomans-81">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1817" data-file-width="3635" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/200px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/300px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/400px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_(cropped).JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="427" data-file-width="1024" height="83" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG/200px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG/300px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG/400px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace_%28cropped%29.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="Topkapı Palace">
           Topkapı
          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="Dolmabahçe Palace">
           Dolmabahçe
          </a>
          palaces were the primary residences of the
          <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
           Ottoman
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="List of sultans of the Ottoman Empire">
           Sultans
          </a>
          and the administrative centre of the empire between 1465 to 1856
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_82-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-nytimes-82">
            [81]
           </a>
          </sup>
          and 1856 to 1922,
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dolmabahcepalace_83-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-dolmabahcepalace-83">
            [82]
           </a>
          </sup>
          respectively.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 1514, Sultan
       <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">
        Selim I
       </a>
       (1512–1520) successfully expanded the empire's southern and eastern borders by defeating Shah
       <a href="/wiki/Ismail_I" title="Ismail I">
        Ismail I
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">
        Safavid dynasty
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chaldiran" title="Battle of Chaldiran">
        Battle of Chaldiran
       </a>
       . In 1517, Selim I expanded Ottoman rule into
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Algeria" title="Ottoman Algeria">
        Algeria
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Mamluk_War_(1516%E2%80%931517)" title="Ottoman–Mamluk War (1516–1517)">
        Egypt
       </a>
       , and created a naval presence in the
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">
        Red Sea
       </a>
       . Subsequently, a contest started between the Ottoman and
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       empires to become the dominant sea power in the
       <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">
        Indian Ocean
       </a>
       , with
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_naval_expeditions_in_the_Indian_Ocean" title="Ottoman naval expeditions in the Indian Ocean">
        a number of naval battles
       </a>
       in the Red Sea, the
       <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">
        Arabian Sea
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">
