        Persian Gulf
       </a>
       . The Portuguese presence in the Indian Ocean was perceived as a threat to the Ottoman monopoly over the
       <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">
        ancient trade routes
       </a>
       between
       <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">
        East Asia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">
        Western Europe
       </a>
       . Despite the increasingly prominent European presence, the Ottoman Empire's trade with the east continued to flourish until the second half of the 18th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Ottoman Empire's power and prestige peaked in the 16th and 17th centuries, particularly during the reign of
       <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">
        Suleiman the Magnificent
       </a>
       , who personally instituted major legislative changes relating to society, education, taxation and criminal law. The empire was often at odds with the
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">
        Holy Roman Empire
       </a>
       in its steady advance towards
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
        Central Europe
       </a>
       through the
       <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
        Balkans
       </a>
       and the southern part of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth">
        Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_85-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-85">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At sea, the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Navy" title="Ottoman Navy">
        Ottoman Navy
       </a>
       contended with several Holy Leagues, such as those in
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1538)" title="Holy League (1538)">
        1538
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1571)" title="Holy League (1571)">
        1571
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1684)" title="Holy League (1684)">
        1684
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1717)" title="Holy League (1717)">
        1717
       </a>
       (composed primarily of
       <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Spain" title="Habsburg Spain">
        Habsburg Spain
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">
        Republic of Genoa
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">
        Republic of Venice
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">
        Knights of St. John
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">
        Papal States
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Tuscany" title="Grand Duchy of Tuscany">
        Grand Duchy of Tuscany
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Savoy" title="Duchy of Savoy">
        Duchy of Savoy
       </a>
       ), for the control of the
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
        Mediterranean Sea
       </a>
       . In the east, the Ottomans were often at war with Safavid Persia over conflicts stemming from territorial disputes or religious differences between the 16th and 18th centuries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman-Persian_Wars" title="Ottoman-Persian Wars">
        Ottoman wars with Persia
       </a>
       continued as the
       <a href="/wiki/Zand_dynasty" title="Zand dynasty">
        Zand
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty" title="Afsharid dynasty">
        Afsharid
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">
        Qajar
       </a>
       dynasties succeeded the Safavids in Iran, until the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Persian_War_(1821%E2%80%9323)" title="Ottoman–Persian War (1821–23)">
        first half of the 19th century
       </a>
       . From the 16th to the early 20th centuries, the Ottoman Empire also
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_Wars" title="Russo-Turkish Wars">
        fought many wars
       </a>
       with the
       <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">
        Russian Tsardom
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
        Empire
       </a>
       . These were initially about Ottoman territorial expansion and consolidation in southeastern and eastern Europe; but starting from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1768%E2%80%9374)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1768–74)">
        latter half of the 18th century
       </a>
       , they became more about the survival of the Ottoman Empire, which had begun to lose its strategic territories on the northern
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
        Black Sea
       </a>
       coast to the advancing Russians.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kaiser_und_Sultan_-_postcard.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="666" data-file-width="1094" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Kaiser_und_Sultan_-_postcard.jpg/220px-Kaiser_und_Sultan_-_postcard.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Kaiser_und_Sultan_-_postcard.jpg/330px-Kaiser_und_Sultan_-_postcard.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Kaiser_und_Sultan_-_postcard.jpg/440px-Kaiser_und_Sultan_-_postcard.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kaiser_und_Sultan_-_postcard.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Visit of
         <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor" title="Wilhelm II, German Emperor">
          Kaiser Wilhelm II
         </a>
         to
         <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">
          Constantinople
         </a>
         in Oct. 1917 with
         <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_V" title="Mehmed V">
          Mehmed V
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Enver_Pasha" title="Enver Pasha">
          Enver Pasha
         </a>
         . The Ottomans joined
         <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
          World War I
         </a>
         on the side of the
         <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">
          Central Powers
         </a>
         and suffered heavy losses. Overall, the total number of combatant casualties in the Ottoman forces amounts to just under half of all those mobilised to fight. Of these, more than 800,000 were killed. However, four out of every five Ottoman subjects who died were non-combatants.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britishcouncil.org1_87-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-britishcouncil.org1-87">
           [86]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       From the second half of the 18th century onwards, the Ottoman Empire
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Decline of the Ottoman Empire">
        began to decline
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">
        Tanzimat
       </a>
       reforms of the 19th century, which had been instituted by
       <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_II" title="Mahmud II">
        Mahmud II
       </a>
       , were aimed to modernise the Ottoman state in line with the progress that had been made in Western Europe. The efforts of
       <a href="/wiki/Midhat_Pasha" title="Midhat Pasha">
        Midhat Pasha
       </a>
       during the late Tanzimat era led the Ottoman
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">
        constitutional movement of 1876
       </a>
       , which introduced the
       <a href="/wiki/First_Constitutional_Era" title="First Constitutional Era">
        First Constitutional Era
       </a>
       , but these efforts proved to be inadequate in most fields, and failed to stop the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Dissolution of the Ottoman Empire">
        dissolution of the empire
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OttoTurkVis_88-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-OttoTurkVis-88">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As the empire gradually shrank in size, military power and wealth, especially after the
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Eastern_Crisis" title="Great Eastern Crisis">
        Ottoman economic crisis and default in 1875
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NiallFergusonFT_89-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NiallFergusonFT-89">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which led to uprisings in the Balkan provinces that culminated into the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%9378)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–78)">
        Russo-Turkish War of 1877–78
       </a>
       , many Balkan Muslims migrated to the Empire's heartland in Anatolia,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Illinois2009_90-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Illinois2009-90">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       along with the
       <a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">
        Circassians
       </a>
       fleeing the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian%E2%80%93Circassian_War" title="Russian–Circassian War">
        Russian conquest
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_conquest_of_the_Caucasus" title="Russian conquest of the Caucasus">
        Caucasus
       </a>
       . The decline of the Ottoman Empire led to a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rise_of_nationalism_under_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of nationalism under the Ottoman Empire">
        rise in nationalist sentiment among its various subject peoples
       </a>
       , leading to increased ethnic tensions which occasionally burst into violence, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Hamidian_massacres" title="Hamidian massacres">
        Hamidian massacres
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">
        Armenians
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nzhistory.net.nz_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nzhistory.net.nz-92">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Young_Turk_Revolution" title="Young Turk Revolution">
        Young Turk Revolution
       </a>
       in 1908
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Constitutional_Era" title="Second Constitutional Era">
        restored
       </a>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">
        Ottoman constitution
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="General Assembly of the Ottoman Empire">
        parliament
       </a>
       30 years after their
       <a href="/wiki/First_Constitutional_Era" title="First Constitutional Era">
        suspension
       </a>
       by Sultan
       <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Hamid_II" title="Abdul Hamid II">
        Abdülhamid II
       </a>
       in 1878, which is known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Constitutional_Era" title="Second Constitutional Era">
        Second Constitutional Era
       </a>
       , but the
       <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d'état">
        1913 Ottoman coup d'état
       </a>
       effectively put the country under the control of the
       <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">
        Three Pashas
       </a>
       , making sultans
       <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_V" title="Mehmed V">
        Mehmed V
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_VI" title="Mehmed VI">
        Mehmed VI
       </a>
       largely symbolic figureheads with no real political power.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Ottoman Empire entered
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       on the side of the
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">
        Central Powers
       </a>
       and was ultimately defeated. During the war, the empire's Armenians were
       <a href="/wiki/Tehcir_Law" title="Tehcir Law">
        deported
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">
        Syria
       </a>
       as part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" title="Armenian Genocide">
        Armenian Genocide
       </a>
       . As a result, an estimated 800,000 to 1,500,000 Armenians were killed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
        <a href="#cite_note-96">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Turkish government has
       <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide_denial" title="Armenian Genocide denial">
        refused to acknowledge
       </a>
       the events as
       <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">
        genocide
       </a>
       and claims that Armenians were only
       <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer" title="Population transfer">
        relocated
       </a>
       from the eastern war zone.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Genocidal campaigns were also committed against the empire's other minority groups such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" title="Assyrian genocide">
        Assyrians
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">
        Greeks
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloxham2005_98-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Bloxham2005-98">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Levene_99-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Levene-99">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ferguson_100-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ferguson-100">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Following the
       <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros" title="Armistice of Mudros">
        Armistice of Mudros
       </a>
       on 30 October 1918, the victorious
       <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">
        Allied Powers
       </a>
       sought to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partitioning_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Partitioning of the Ottoman Empire">
        partition the Ottoman state
       </a>
       through the 1920
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of Sèvres">
        Treaty of Sèvres
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ottomans_81-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ottomans-81">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_of_Turkey">
        Republic of Turkey
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="History of the Republic of Turkey">
        History of the Republic of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">
        Atatürk's Reforms
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_visits_a_school.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="1024" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Ataturk_visits_a_school.jpg/250px-Ataturk_visits_a_school.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Ataturk_visits_a_school.jpg/375px-Ataturk_visits_a_school.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Ataturk_visits_a_school.jpg/500px-Ataturk_visits_a_school.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_visits_a_school.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">
          Mustafa Kemal Atatürk
         </a>
         , founder and first President of the Turkish Republic, visiting
         <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">
          Istanbul University
         </a>
         after its
         <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">
          reorganization
         </a>
         in 1933 as a
         <a href="/wiki/Mixed-sex_education" title="Mixed-sex education">
          mixed-gender
         </a>
         institution of
         <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">
          higher education
         </a>
         with multiple
         <a href="/wiki/Faculty_(division)" title="Faculty (division)">
          faculties
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Constantinople" title="Occupation of Constantinople">
        occupation of Istanbul
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Smyrna" title="Occupation of Smyrna">
        Izmir
       </a>
       by the Allies in the aftermath of World War I prompted the establishment of the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_National_Movement" title="Turkish National Movement">
        Turkish National Movement
       </a>
       . Under the leadership of
       <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">
        Mustafa Kemal
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Pasha" title="Pasha">
        Pasha
       </a>
       , a military commander who had distinguished himself during the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gallipoli" title="Battle of Gallipoli">
        Battle of Gallipoli
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">
        Turkish War of Independence
       </a>
       was waged with the aim of revoking the terms of the Treaty of Sèvres.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atatürk_101-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Atatürk-101">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       By 18 September 1922 the Greek, Armenian and French armies were expelled,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18sep1922_102-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-18sep1922-102">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Provisional_Government" title="Turkish Provisional Government">
        Ankara-based Turkish regime
       </a>
       , which had declared itself the legitimate government of the country on
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">
        23 April 1920
       </a>
       , started to formalise the legal transition from the old Ottoman into the new Republican political system. On 1 November 1922, the
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">
        Turkish Parliament
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">
        Ankara
       </a>
       formally
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Ottoman_Sultanate" title="Abolition of the Ottoman Sultanate">
        abolished the Sultanate
       </a>
       , thus ending 623 years of monarchical Ottoman rule. The
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">
        Treaty of Lausanne
       </a>
       of 24 July 1923 led to the international recognition of the sovereignty of the newly formed "Republic of Turkey" as the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, and the republic was officially proclaimed on 29 October 1923 in Ankara, the country's new capital.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Convention_Concerning_the_Exchange_of_Greek_and_Turkish_Populations" title="Convention Concerning the Exchange of Greek and Turkish Populations">
        Lausanne Convention
       </a>
       stipulated a
       <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">
        population exchange between Greece and Turkey
       </a>
       , whereby 1.1 million Greeks left Turkey for Greece in exchange for 380,000 Muslims transferred from Greece to Turkey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clogg_104-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Clogg-104">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Mustafa Kemal became the republic's first
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">
        President
       </a>
       and subsequently introduced
       <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">
        many radical reforms
       </a>
       with the aim of transforming the old
       <a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">
        religion-based and multi-communal
       </a>
       Ottoman state system (
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">
        constitutional
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">
        monarchy
       </a>
       ) into an essentially Turkish
       <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">
        nation state
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">
        parliamentary republic
       </a>
       ) with a
       <a href="/wiki/La%C3%AFcit%C3%A9" title="Laïcité">
        secular
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution_of_1924" title="Turkish Constitution of 1924">
        constitution
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BoweringCrone2012_105-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BoweringCrone2012-105">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With the
       <a href="/wiki/Surname_Law" title="Surname Law">
        Surname Law
       </a>
       of 1934, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Parliament" title="Turkish Parliament">
        Turkish Parliament
       </a>
       bestowed upon Mustafa Kemal the honorific surname "Atatürk" (
       <i>
        Father of the Turks
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atatürk_101-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Atatürk-101">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_(1935).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="299" data-file-width="392" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg/220px-First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg/330px-First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_(1935).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Eighteen female
         <a href="/wiki/Member_of_parliament" title="Member of parliament">
          deputies
         </a>
         joined the
         <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">
          Turkish Parliament
         </a>
         with the
         <a href="/wiki/Turkish_general_election,_1935" title="Turkish general election, 1935">
          1935 general elections
         </a>
         . Turkish women gained the
         <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_women%27s_suffrage" title="Timeline of women's suffrage">
          right to vote
         </a>
         a decade or more before women in Western European countries like France, Italy, and Belgium, a mark of Atatürk's far-reaching social changes.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
          <a href="#cite_note-106">
           [105]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC" title="İsmet İnönü">
        İsmet İnönü
       </a>
       became Turkey's second President following Atatürk's death on 10 November 1938. In 1939 Turkey annexed the
       <a href="/wiki/Hatay_State" title="Hatay State">
        Republic of Hatay
       </a>
       . Turkey
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Cairo_Conference" title="Second Cairo Conference">
        remained neutral
       </a>
       during most of
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , but entered the closing stages of the war on the side of the
       <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">
        Allies
       </a>
       on 23 February 1945. On 26 June 1945, Turkey became a
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" title="United Nations Charter">
        charter member
       </a>
       of the United Nations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turkey_UN_107-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Turkey_UN-107">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the same year, the
       <a href="/wiki/One-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="One-party period of the Republic of Turkey">
        single-party period
       </a>
       in Turkey came to an end, with the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_general_election,_1946" title="Turkish general election, 1946">
        first multiparty elections in 1946
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Truman_Doctrine" title="Truman Doctrine">
        Truman Doctrine
       </a>
       in 1947 enunciated American intentions to guarantee the security of Turkey and Greece during the
       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
        Cold War
       </a>
       , and resulted in large-scale
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkey-United_States_relations" title="Turkey-United States relations">
        U.S. military and economic support
       </a>
       . In 1948 both countries were included in the
       <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">
        Marshall Plan
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_European_Economic_Co-operation" title="Organisation for European Economic Co-operation">
        OEEC
       </a>
       for rebuilding European economies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Truman_Doctrine_108-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Truman_Doctrine-108">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1949 Turkey became a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Democrat_Party_(Turkey,_1946%E2%80%9361)" title="Democrat Party (Turkey, 1946–61)">
        Democratic Party
       </a>
       established by
       <a href="/wiki/Cel%C3%A2l_Bayar" title="Celâl Bayar">
        Celâl Bayar
       </a>
       won the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_general_election,_1950" title="Turkish general election, 1950">
        1950
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_general_election,_1954" title="Turkish general election, 1954">
        1954
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_general_election,_1957" title="Turkish general election, 1957">
        1957
       </a>
       general elections and stayed in power for a decade, with
       <a href="/wiki/Adnan_Menderes" title="Adnan Menderes">
        Adnan Menderes
       </a>
       as the Prime Minister and Bayar as the President. After participating with the United Nations forces in the
       <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">
        Korean War
       </a>
       , Turkey joined
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       in 1952, becoming a bulwark against Soviet expansion into the
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">
        Mediterranean
       </a>
       . Turkey subsequently became a founding member of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD
       </a>
       in 1961, and an
       <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">
        associate member
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">
        EEC
       </a>
       in 1963.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd.org_109-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-oecd.org-109">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:137px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gursel_and_Norstad.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="381" data-file-width="217" height="237" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Gursel_and_Norstad.jpg/135px-Gursel_and_Norstad.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Gursel_and_Norstad.jpg/203px-Gursel_and_Norstad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b4/Gursel_and_Norstad.jpg 2x" width="135"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gursel_and_Norstad.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         During the politically unstable periods of the Turkish Republic,
         <a href="/wiki/1960_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1960 Turkish coup d'état">
          the military exercised power
         </a>
         directly or through figures like
         <a href="/wiki/Cemal_G%C3%BCrsel" title="Cemal Gürsel">
          Cemal Gürsel
         </a>
         (far right).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The country's tumultuous transition to
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Multi-party period of the Republic of Turkey">
        multiparty democracy
       </a>
       was interrupted by military
       <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">
        coups d'état
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/1960_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1960 Turkish coup d'état">
        1960
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1971_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1971 Turkish coup d'état">
        1971
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/1980_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1980 Turkish coup d'état">
        1980
       </a>
       , as well as a military memorandum in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1997_military_memorandum_(Turkey)" title="1997 military memorandum (Turkey)">
        1997
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRPoliticsandMilitary_110-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TRPoliticsandMilitary-110">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Between 1960 and the end of the 20th century, the prominent leaders in Turkish politics who achieved multiple election victories were
       <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCleyman_Demirel" title="Süleyman Demirel">
        Süleyman Demirel
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/B%C3%BClent_Ecevit" title="Bülent Ecevit">
        Bülent Ecevit
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Turgut_%C3%96zal" title="Turgut Özal">
        Turgut Özal
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Following a decade of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cypriot_intercommunal_violence" title="Cypriot intercommunal violence">
        Cypriot intercommunal violence
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/1974_Cypriot_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1974 Cypriot coup d'état">
        coup in Cyprus on 15 July 1974
       </a>
       staged by the
       <a href="/wiki/EOKA_B" title="EOKA B">
        EOKA B
       </a>
       paramilitary organisation, which overthrew President
       <a href="/wiki/Makarios_III" title="Makarios III">
        Makarios
       </a>
       and installed the pro-
       <a href="/wiki/Enosis" title="Enosis">
        Enosis
       </a>
       (union with Greece)
       <a href="/wiki/Nikos_Sampson" title="Nikos Sampson">
        Nikos Sampson
       </a>
       as dictator,
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_invasion_of_Cyprus" title="Turkish invasion of Cyprus">
        Turkey invaded Cyprus
       </a>
       on 20 July 1974 by unilaterally exercising Article IV in the
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Guarantee_(1960)" title="Treaty of Guarantee (1960)">
        Treaty of Guarantee (1960)
       </a>
       , but without restoring the
       <a href="/wiki/Status_quo_ante_bellum" title="Status quo ante bellum">
        status quo ante
       </a>
       at the end of the military operation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Uslu2003_112-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Uslu2003-112">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1983 the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Republic_of_Northern_Cyprus" title="Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus">
        Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus
       </a>
       , which is recognised only by Turkey, was established.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2017, negotiations for solving the
       <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">
        Cyprus dispute
       </a>
       are still ongoing between
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Cypriots" title="Turkish Cypriots">
        Turkish Cypriot
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_Cypriots" title="Greek Cypriots">
        Greek Cypriot
       </a>
       political leaders.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1984, the
       <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Workers%27_Party" title="Kurdistan Workers' Party">
        Kurdistan Workers' Party
       </a>
       (PKK), a Kurdish separatist group (listed as a
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_designated_terrorist_groups" title="List of designated terrorist groups">
        terrorist organization
       </a>
       by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization" title="North Atlantic Treaty Organization">
        NATO
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
        United States
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       ), began an
       <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_rebellions_in_Turkey" title="Kurdish rebellions in Turkey">
        armed insurgency campaign
       </a>
       against Turkey. The conflict has claimed over 40,000 lives to date.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the liberalisation of the Turkish economy in the 1980s, the country has enjoyed stronger economic growth and greater political stability.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80sLiberalization_116-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-80sLiberalization-116">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey applied for full membership of the EEC in 1987, joined the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">
        EU Customs Union
       </a>
       in 1995 and started
       <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">
        accession negotiations
       </a>
       with the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       in 2005.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_31-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-31">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2013,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2013_protests_in_Turkey" title="2013 protests in Turkey">
        widespread protests
       </a>
       erupted in many Turkish provinces, sparked by a plan to demolish
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gezi_Park" title="Gezi Park">
        Gezi Park
       </a>
       but soon growing into general anti-government dissent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 15 July 2016, an
       <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt">
        unsuccessful coup attempt
       </a>
       tried to oust the government.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a reaction to the failed coup d'état, the government is currently carrying out
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Turkish_purges" title="2016–17 Turkish purges">
        mass purges
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes.comxx_119-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nytimes.comxx-119">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkeypurge.com_120-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-turkeypurge.com-120">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
        Administrative divisions
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Turkey" title="Administrative divisions of Turkey">
        Administrative divisions of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regions_of_Turkey" title="Regions of Turkey">
        Regions of Turkey
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NUTS_of_Turkey" title="NUTS of Turkey">
        NUTS of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Turkey has a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary
       </a>
       structure in terms of administration and this aspect is one of the most important factors shaping the Turkish public administration. When three powers (executive, legislative and judiciary) are taken into account as the main functions of the state, local administrations have little power. Turkey doesn't have a
       <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">
        federal
       </a>
       system, and the provinces are subordinate to the central government in Ankara. Local administrations were established to provide services in place and the government is represented by the province governors (
       <i>
        vali
       </i>
       ) and town governors (
       <i>
        kaymakam
       </i>
       ). Other senior public officials are also appointed by the central government instead of the mayors (
       <i>
        belediye başkanı
       </i>
       ) or elected by constituents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-justice.gov.tr_121-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-justice.gov.tr-121">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkish municipalities have local legislative bodies (
       <i>
        belediye meclisi
       </i>
       ) for decision-making on municipal issues.
      </p>
      <p>
       Within this unitary framework, Turkey is subdivided into 81
       <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">
        provinces
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        il
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        vilayet
       </i>
       ) for administrative purposes. Each province is divided into
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Districts_of_Turkey" title="Districts of Turkey">
        districts
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        ilçe
       </i>
       ), for a total of 923 districts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey is also subdivided into 7
       <a href="/wiki/Geographical_regions_of_Turkey" title="Geographical regions of Turkey">
        regions
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        bölge
       </i>
       ) and 21 subregions for geographic, demographic and economic purposes; this does not refer to an administrative division. The centralised structure of decision-making in Ankara is considered by some academicians as an impediment to good local governance,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-afd_123-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-afd-123">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-joppien_124-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-joppien-124">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and occasionally causes resentment in the municipalities of urban centres that are inhabited largely by ethnic minority groups, such as the Kurds.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-carnegie_125-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-carnegie-125">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Steps towards decentralisation since 2004 have proven to be a highly controversial topic in Turkey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-afd_123-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-afd-123">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-joppien_124-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-joppien-124">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The efforts to decentralise the administrative structure are also driven by the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_of_Local_Self-Government" title="European Charter of Local Self-Government">
        European Charter of Local Self-Government
       </a>
       and with Chapter 22 ("Regional Policy &amp; Coordination of Structural Instruments") of the
       <a href="/wiki/Acquis_communautaire" title="Acquis communautaire">
        <i>
         acquis
        </i>
        of the European Union
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A decentralisation program for Turkey has been a topic of discussion in the country's academics, politics and the broader public.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sayan_131-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-sayan-131">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <center>
       <div class="noresize" role="img" style="width: 700px; float: none; clear: none; font-size: 85%; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative; max-width: 100%; overflow-x: auto;">

          Şırnak
         </a>
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute; left:587.6px; top:197.8px">
         <a href="/wiki/Bitlis_Province" title="Bitlis Province">
          Bitlis
         </a>
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute; left:528.8px; top:169.8px">
         <a href="/wiki/Bing%C3%B6l_Province" title="Bingöl Province">
          Bingöl
         </a>
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute; left:569.4px; top:171.2px">
         <a href="/wiki/Mu%C5%9F_Province" title="Muş Province">
          Muş
         </a>
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute; left:643.6px; top:190.8px">
         <a href="/wiki/Van_Province" title="Van Province">
          Van
         </a>
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute; left:657.6px; top:235.6px">
         <a href="/wiki/Hakk%C3%A2ri_Province" title="Hakkâri Province">
          Hakkâri
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="floatright">
         <a href="/wiki/Template:Turkey_Labelled_Map" title="Template:Turkey Labelled Map">
          <img alt="Desc-i.svg" data-file-height="648" data-file-width="648" height="20" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Desc-i.svg/20px-Desc-i.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Desc-i.svg/30px-Desc-i.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Desc-i.svg/40px-Desc-i.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </center>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
        Politics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Turkey" title="Politics of Turkey">
        Politics of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">
        Constitution of Turkey
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Turkey" title="Elections in Turkey">
        Elections in Turkey
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ministries_of_Turkey" title="Ministries of Turkey">
        Ministries of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:right; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;">
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG">
          <img alt="Recep Tayyip Erdogan.PNG" data-file-height="488" data-file-width="370" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/121px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/182px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/242px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG 2x" width="121"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:left;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg">
          <img alt="Binali Yıldırım.jpg" data-file-height="369" data-file-width="276" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg/120px-Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg/180px-Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg/240px-Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">
          Tayyip Erdoğan
         </a>
         <br/>
         <small>
          <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">
           President
          </a>
         </small>
        </td>
        <td style="text-align:center;">
         <a href="/wiki/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m" title="Binali Yıldırım">
          Binali Yıldırım
         </a>
         <br/>
         <small>
          <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Turkey" title="Prime Minister of Turkey">
           Prime Minister
          </a>
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">
        Constitutionally
       </a>
       , Turkey is a
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
        parliamentary
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">
        representative democracy
       </a>
       . Since its foundation as a republic in 1923, Turkey has developed
       <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">
        a strong tradition
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">
        secularism
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_Secularism_134-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TR_Secularism-134">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">
        Turkey's constitution
       </a>
       governs the legal framework of the country. It sets out the main principles of government and establishes Turkey as a unitary centralised state. The
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Turkey" title="List of Presidents of Turkey">
        President of the Republic
       </a>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       and has a largely ceremonial role. The president is elected for a five-year term by direct elections and
       <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip Erdoğan">
        Tayyip Erdoğan
       </a>
       is the first president elected by direct voting.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">
        Executive power
       </a>
       is exercised by the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Turkey" title="List of Prime Ministers of Turkey">
        Prime Minister
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Turkey" title="Council of Ministers of Turkey">
        Council of Ministers
       </a>
       which make up the government, while the
       <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">
        legislative
       </a>
       power is vested in the unicameral parliament, the
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">
        Grand National Assembly of Turkey
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">
        judiciary
       </a>
       is independent of the executive and the legislature, and the Constitutional Court is charged with ruling on the conformity of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_System_in_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Legal System in the Republic of Turkey">
        laws and decrees
       </a>
       with the constitution. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Council_of_State" title="Turkish Council of State">
        Council of State
       </a>
       is the tribunal of last resort for administrative cases, and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Appeals_of_Turkey" title="High Court of Appeals of Turkey">
        High Court of Appeals
       </a>
       for all others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_Constit_135-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TR_Constit-135">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The prime minister is elected by the parliament through a vote of confidence in the government and is most often the head of the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Turkey" title="List of political parties in Turkey">
        party
       </a>
       having the most seats in parliament. The prime minister is
       <a href="/wiki/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m" title="Binali Yıldırım">
        Binali Yıldırım
       </a>
       , who replaced
       <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Davuto%C4%9Flu" title="Ahmet Davutoğlu">
        Ahmet Davutoğlu
       </a>
       on 24 May 2016.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">
        Universal suffrage
       </a>
       for both sexes has been applied throughout Turkey since 1933 and before most countries, and every Turkish citizen who has turned 18 years of age has the right to vote. There are 550
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament" title="Member of Parliament">
        members of parliament
       </a>
       who are elected for a four-year term by a
       <a href="/wiki/Party-list_proportional_representation" title="Party-list proportional representation">
        party-list proportional representation
       </a>
       system from 85 electoral districts. The Constitutional Court can strip the public financing of
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Turkey" title="List of political parties in Turkey">
        political parties
       </a>
       that it deems
       <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">
        anti-secular
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Separatism" title="Separatism">
        separatist
       </a>
       , or ban their existence altogether.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electoral_threshold" title="Electoral threshold">
        electoral threshold
       </a>
       is 10 percent of the votes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BYEGM_TrPolSys_138-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BYEGM_TrPolSys-138">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Supporters of
       <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="Atatürk's Reforms">
        Atatürk's reforms
       </a>
       are called
       <a href="/wiki/Kemalism" title="Kemalism">
        Kemalists
       </a>
       , as distinguished from
       <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">
        Islamists
       </a>
       , representing the two diverging views regarding the
       <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">
        role of religion
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Legislation" title="Legislation">
        legislation
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Education" title="Education">
        education
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_life" title="Public life">
        public life
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_139-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-139">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Kemalist view supports a form of
       <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">
        democracy
       </a>
       with a
       <a href="/wiki/La%C3%AFcit%C3%A9" title="Laïcité">
        laicist
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution" title="Constitution">
        constitution
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">
        Westernised
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">
        secular
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Lifestyle_(sociology)" title="Lifestyle (sociology)">
        lifestyle
       </a>
       , while maintaining the necessity of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_intervention" title="State intervention">
        state intervention
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Economy" title="Economy">
        economy
       </a>
       , education and other
       <a href="/wiki/Public_service" title="Public service">
        public services
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_139-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-139">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since the 1980s, issues such as income inequality and class distinction have given rise to
       <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">
        Islamic populism
       </a>
       , a movement that supports a larger role for religion in government policies, and in theory supports obligation to authority, communal solidarity and social justice; though what that entails in practice is often contested.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_139-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-139">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey under Tayyip Erdoğan and the AKP has been described as becoming increasingly
       <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">
        authoritarian
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Prior to the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_constitutional_referendum,_2017" title="Turkish constitutional referendum, 2017">
        constitutional referendum in 2017
       </a>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       saw Turkey drifting towards an
       <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">
        autocracy
       </a>
       , warning of a "dramatic regression of its democratic order".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of 2016 the
       <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">
        Economist Intelligence Unit
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">
        Democracy Index
       </a>
       rates Turkey at 5.03 (on a 0–10 scale), classifying Turkey as a
       <i>
        Hybrid Regime
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-index2016_147-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-index2016-147">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2017
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
        Freedom House
       </a>
       rated Turkey at 38 (on a 0–100 scale) as
       <i>
        Partly Free
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
        <a href="#cite_note-148">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The constitutional referendum was held in April 2017 to change the
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">
        parliamentary system
       </a>
       to a
       <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">
        presidential system
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many elements in this constitutional reform package have increased concerns in Europe regarding democracy and separation of powers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-euronewsreferendum_150-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-euronewsreferendum-150">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-independent.co.ukx_151-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-independent.co.ukx-151">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The referendum ended in favor of change.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">
        Human rights
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">
        Human rights in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Racism_in_Turkey" title="Racism in Turkey">
        Racism in Turkey
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Torture_in_Turkey" title="Torture in Turkey">
        Torture in Turkey
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_Turkey" title="Censorship in Turkey">
        Censorship in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2013_Taksim_Gezi_Park_protests,_a_view_from_Taksim_Gezi_Park_on_4th_June_2013_3.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/2013_Taksim_Gezi_Park_protests%2C_a_view_from_Taksim_Gezi_Park_on_4th_June_2013_3.JPG/250px-2013_Taksim_Gezi_Park_protests%2C_a_view_from_Taksim_Gezi_Park_on_4th_June_2013_3.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/2013_Taksim_Gezi_Park_protests%2C_a_view_from_Taksim_Gezi_Park_on_4th_June_2013_3.JPG/375px-2013_Taksim_Gezi_Park_protests%2C_a_view_from_Taksim_Gezi_Park_on_4th_June_2013_3.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/2013_Taksim_Gezi_Park_protests%2C_a_view_from_Taksim_Gezi_Park_on_4th_June_2013_3.JPG/500px-2013_Taksim_Gezi_Park_protests%2C_a_view_from_Taksim_Gezi_Park_on_4th_June_2013_3.JPG 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2013_Taksim_Gezi_Park_protests,_a_view_from_Taksim_Gezi_Park_on_4th_June_2013_3.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A view from the
         <a href="/wiki/Gezi_Park_protests" title="Gezi Park protests">
          Gezi Park protests
         </a>
         a view from
         <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Square" title="Taksim Square">
          Taksim Square
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
          Istanbul
         </a>
         on 4 June 2013.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">
        Human rights in Turkey
       </a>
       have been the subject of some controversy and international condemnation. Between 1998 and 2008 the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights" title="European Court of Human Rights">
        European Court of Human Rights
       </a>
       made more than 1,600 judgements against Turkey for human rights violations, particularly regarding the right to life, and freedom from torture. Other issues, such as Kurdish rights, women's rights, LGBT rights, and press freedom, have also attracted controversy. Turkey's human rights record continues to be a significant obstacle to future membership of the EU.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
        <a href="#cite_note-154">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the
       <a href="/wiki/Committee_to_Protect_Journalists" title="Committee to Protect Journalists">
        Committee to Protect Journalists
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">
        AKP
       </a>
       government has waged one of the world's biggest crackdowns on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Turkey" title="Media freedom in Turkey">
        media freedom
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPJ_155-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CPJ-155">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cpj.org1_156-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cpj.org1-156">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A large number of journalists have been arrested using charges of "terrorism" and "anti-state activities" such as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ergenekon_(organization)" title="Ergenekon (organization)">
        Ergenekon
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sledgehammer_(coup_plan)" title="Sledgehammer (coup plan)">
        Balyoz
       </a>
       cases, while thousands have been investigated on charges such as "denigrating Turkishness" or "insulting Islam" in an effort to sow self-censorship.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPJ_155-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-CPJ-155">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2017, the CPJ identified 81 jailed journalists in Turkey (including the editorial staff of
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Cumhuriyet" title="Cumhuriyet">
         Cumhuriyet
        </a>
       </i>
       , Turkey's oldest newspaper still in circulation), all directly held for their published work (ranking 1st in the world, more than in Iran, Eritrea or China);
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cpj.org1_156-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cpj.org1-156">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while Freemuse identified 9 musicians imprisoned for their work (ranking 3rd after Russia and China).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freemuse_157-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-freemuse-157">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A former
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">
        US State Department
       </a>
       spokesman,
       <a href="/wiki/Philip_J._Crowley" title="Philip J. Crowley">
        Philip J. Crowley
       </a>
       , said that the United States had "broad concerns about trends involving intimidation of journalists in Turkey."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey's media is rated as
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_Press_(report)" title="Freedom of the Press (report)">
        <i>
         not free
        </i>
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
        Freedom House
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_159-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-159">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In its resolution "The functioning of democratic institutions in Turkey" on 22 June 2016, the
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_Assembly_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe">
        Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe
       </a>
       warned that "recent developments in Turkey pertaining to freedom of the media and of expression, erosion of the rule of law and the human rights violations in relation to anti-terrorism security operations in south-east Turkey have (...) raised serious questions about the functioning of its democratic institutions."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 20 May 2016, the Turkish parliament stripped almost a quarter of its members of
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_immunity" title="Parliamentary immunity">
        immunity
       </a>
       from prosecution, including 101 deputies from the pro-Kurdish
       <a href="/wiki/Peoples%27_Democratic_Party_(Turkey)" title="Peoples' Democratic Party (Turkey)">
        HDP
       </a>
       and the main opposition
       <a href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party_(Turkey)" title="Republican People's Party (Turkey)">
        CHP
       </a>
       party.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In reaction to the
       <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt">
        failed coup d'état
       </a>
       on 15 July 2016, over 125,000 judges, teachers, police and civil servants have been suspended or dismissed, 36,000 have been formally arrested, and 130 media organisations, including 16 television broadcasters and 45 newspapers,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       have been closed by the government of Turkey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On 29 April 2017, Turkish authorities
       <a href="/wiki/2017_block_of_Wikipedia_in_Turkey" title="2017 block of Wikipedia in Turkey">
        blocked online access to Wikipedia
       </a>
       in all languages across Turkey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tb_164-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tb-164">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_165-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBC-165">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The restrictions were imposed in the context of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Turkish_purges" title="2016–17 Turkish purges">
        2016–17 purges
       </a>
       following the
       <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt">
        2016 Turkish
        <i>
         coup d'état
        </i>
        attempt
       </a>
       , a few weeks after a significant
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_constitutional_referendum,_2017" title="Turkish constitutional referendum, 2017">
        constitutional referendum
       </a>
       , and following more selective
       <a href="/wiki/Censorship_of_Wikipedia#Turkey" title="Censorship of Wikipedia">
        partial blocking of Wikipedia content
       </a>
       in previous years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kingsley_166-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Kingsley-166">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Following the ban,
       <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Wales" title="Jimmy Wales">
        Jimmy Wales
       </a>
       , Wikipedia's founder, was disinvited from the World Cities Expo in
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
        Istanbul
       </a>
       from 15 to 18 May.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tpjw_167-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tpjw-167">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkish law professor Yaman Akdeniz estimates that wikipedia is one of about 127,000 websites blocked by Turkish authorities. An estimated 45 percent of Turks have circumvented the Internet blocks, at one time or another, by using a
       <a href="/wiki/Virtual_private_network" title="Virtual private network">
        virtual private network
       </a>
       (VPN).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Law">
        Law
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Turkey" title="Judicial system of Turkey">
        Judicial system of Turkey
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Turkey" title="Law enforcement in Turkey">
        Law enforcement in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Suleiman_bas-relief_in_the_U.S._House_of_Representatives_chamber.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="320" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Suleiman_bas-relief_in_the_U.S._House_of_Representatives_chamber.jpg/200px-Suleiman_bas-relief_in_the_U.S._House_of_Representatives_chamber.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Suleiman_bas-relief_in_the_U.S._House_of_Representatives_chamber.jpg/300px-Suleiman_bas-relief_in_the_U.S._House_of_Representatives_chamber.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fc/Suleiman_bas-relief_in_the_U.S._House_of_Representatives_chamber.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Suleiman_bas-relief_in_the_U.S._House_of_Representatives_chamber.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Bas-relief of the
         <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
          Ottoman
         </a>
         emperor
         <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">
          Suleiman the Magnificent
         </a>
         , known in Turkish as "the Lawgiver", in the chamber of the U.S. House of Representatives.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Turkey" title="Judicial system of Turkey">
        Turkey's judicial system
       </a>
       has been wholly integrated with the
       <a href="/wiki/Law_in_Europe" title="Law in Europe">
        system of continental Europe
       </a>
       . For instance, the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_civil_code_(1926)" title="Turkish civil code (1926)">
        Turkish Civil Code
       </a>
       has been modified by incorporating elements mainly of the
       <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Civil_Code" title="Swiss Civil Code">
        Swiss Civil Code
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Code_of_Obligations" title="Swiss Code of Obligations">
        Code of Obligations
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Germany" title="Law of Germany">
        German Commercial Code
       </a>
       . The Administrative Code bears similarities with its
       <a href="/wiki/Law_of_France" title="Law of France">
        French counterpart
       </a>
       , and the Penal Code with its
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_law_codes" title="Italian law codes">
        Italian counterpart
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mymerhaba.com_169-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mymerhaba.com-169">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Turkey has adopted the principle of the
       <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">
        separation of powers
       </a>
       . In line with this principle, judicial power is exercised by independent courts on behalf of the Turkish nation. The independence and organisation of the courts, the security of the tenure of judges and public prosecutors, the profession of judges and prosecutors, the supervision of judges and public prosecutors, the military courts and their organisation, and the powers and duties of the high courts are regulated by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" title="Turkish Constitution">
        Turkish Constitution
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr_170-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr-170">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to Article 142 of the Turkish Constitution, the organisation, duties and jurisdiction of the courts, their functions and the trial procedures are regulated by law. In line with the aforementioned article of the Turkish Constitution and related laws, the court system in Turkey can be classified under three main categories; which are the Judicial Courts, Administrative Courts and Military Courts. Each category includes first instance courts and high courts. In addition, the Court of Jurisdictional Disputes rules on cases that cannot be classified readily as falling within the purview of one court system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr_170-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr-170">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Law enforcement in Turkey is carried out by several departments (such as the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Directorate_of_Security" title="General Directorate of Security">
        General Directorate of Security
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie_General_Command" title="Gendarmerie General Command">
        Gendarmerie General Command
       </a>
       ) and agencies, all acting under the command of the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Turkey" title="Prime Minister of Turkey">
        Prime Minister of Turkey
       </a>
       or mostly the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)">
        Minister of Internal Affairs
       </a>
       . According to figures released by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of Justice (Turkey)">
        Justice Ministry
       </a>
       , there are 100,000 people in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_prisons" title="Turkish prisons">
        Turkish prisons
       </a>
       as of November 2008, a doubling since 2000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the years of government by the
       <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">
        AKP
       </a>
