        Mlahso
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Greek" title="Pontic Greek">
        Pontic Greek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">
        Romani
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suret" title="Suret">
        Suret
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turoyo" title="Turoyo">
        Turoyo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ubykh_language" title="Ubykh language">
        Ubykh
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Armenian" title="Western Armenian">
        Western Armenian
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-www.unesco.org_index_347-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-www.unesco.org_index-347">
         [346]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Turkey" title="Religion in Turkey">
        Religion in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">
        Secularism in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright" style="">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:200px">
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black">
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:Chartreuse">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 791.58150883065px; border-left-color:Honeydew">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Honeydew">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Honeydew">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 181.89932472811px; border-left-color:Black">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Black">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Black">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 72.654252800537px; border-left-color:DodgerBlue">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 54.975465219278px; border-left-color:MediumSeaGreen">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:MediumSeaGreen">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:MediumSeaGreen">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:92.977648588825px 36.812455268468px 0 0; border-top-color:ForestGreen">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:ForestGreen">
         </div>
         <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:80.901699437495px 58.778525229247px 0 0; border-top-color:DarkGreen">
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DarkGreen">
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <p>
          Religion in Turkey (2016)
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ipsos2017_348-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-ipsos2017-348">
            [347]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </p>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:DarkGreen; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">
           Sunni Islam
          </a>
          (65%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:ForestGreen; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">
           Shia Islam
          </a>
          (4%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:MediumSeaGreen; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Unaffiliated Muslims (14%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:DodgerBlue; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
           Christianity
          </a>
          (2%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Black; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">
           Irreligion
          </a>
          (7%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Honeydew; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          <a href="/wiki/Spiritual_but_not_religious" title="Spiritual but not religious">
           Spiritual but not religious
          </a>
          (6%)
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Chartreuse; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Other religions (2%)
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Turkey is a
       <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">
        secular state
       </a>
       with no official
       <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">
        state religion
       </a>
       ; the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" title="Turkish Constitution">
        Turkish Constitution
       </a>
       provides for
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">
        freedom of religion
       </a>
       and conscience.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349">
        <a href="#cite_note-349">
         [348]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350">
        <a href="#cite_note-350">
         [349]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the latest sources by
       <a href="/wiki/Ipsos" title="Ipsos">
        Ipsos
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ipsos2017_348-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ipsos2017-348">
         [347]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in 2016
       <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
        Islam
       </a>
       was the major religion in Turkey comprising only 82% of the total population, followed by the unaffiliated people who comprised 13% of the population, and
       <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
        Christianity
       </a>
       with 2%.
      </p>
      <p>
       The role of religion has been a controversial debate over the years since the formation of Islamist parties.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
        <a href="#cite_note-351">
         [350]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For many decades, the wearing of the
       <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">
        hijab
       </a>
       was
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Headscarf_controversy_in_Turkey" title="Headscarf controversy in Turkey">
        banned
       </a>
       in schools and government buildings because it was viewed as a symbol of
       <a href="/wiki/Political_Islam" title="Political Islam">
        political Islam
       </a>
       . However, the ban was lifted from universities in 2011, from government buildings in 2013,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352">
        <a href="#cite_note-352">
         [351]
        </a>
       </sup>
       from schools in 2014,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-news24.com_353-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-news24.com-353">
         [352]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and from the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">
        Armed Forces
       </a>
       in 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354">
        <a href="#cite_note-354">
         [353]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The government of Tayyip Erdoğan and the Justice and Development Party (AKP) pursue the explicit policy agenda of Islamization of education to "raise a devout generation" against secular resistance,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355">
        <a href="#cite_note-355">
         [354]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356">
        <a href="#cite_note-356">
         [355]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in the process causing lost jobs and school for many non-religious citizens of Turkey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357">
        <a href="#cite_note-357">
         [356]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Islam">
        Islam
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Turkey" title="Islam in Turkey">
        Islam in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="659" data-file-width="930" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg/220px-Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg/330px-Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg/440px-Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque_Istanbul_Turkey_retouched.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque" title="Sultan Ahmed Mosque">
          Sultan Ahmed Mosque
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
          Istanbul
         </a>
         is popularly known as the Blue Mosque due to the blue
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0znik_tiles" title="İznik tiles">
          İznik tiles
         </a>
         which adorn its interior.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bluemosque_358-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-bluemosque-358">
           [357]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       There are no official statistics of people's religious beliefs nor is it asked in the census. According to the government, 99.8%
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-five_360-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-five-360">
         [II]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of the Turkish population is
       <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">
        Muslim
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_252-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-cia-252">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361">
        <a href="#cite_note-361">
         [359]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (although some sources give a slightly lower estimate of 96.4 percent)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-joshua_334-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-joshua-334">
         [333]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with the most popular sect being the
       <a href="/wiki/Hanafi" title="Hanafi">
        Hanafi
       </a>
       school of
       <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">
        Sunni Islam
       </a>
       . There are also some
       <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">
        Sufi
       </a>
       Muslims.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362">
        <a href="#cite_note-362">
         [360]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Roughly 2 percent are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslims" title="Non-denominational Muslims">
        non-denominational Muslims
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewforum.org_363-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pewforum.org-363">
         [361]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The highest Islamic religious authority is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Religious_Affairs" title="Presidency of Religious Affairs">
        Presidency of Religious Affairs
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
        Turkish
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        <span lang="tr">
         Diyanet İşleri Başkanlığı
        </span>
       </i>
       ); it interprets the Hanafi school of law, and is responsible for regulating the operation of the country's 80,000 registered mosques and employing local and provincial
       <a href="/wiki/Imam" title="Imam">
        imams
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religiousfreedomreport_364-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-religiousfreedomreport-364">
         [362]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some have also complained (see cite) that under the
       <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">
        Islamist
       </a>
       government of the Justice and Development Party (AKP) and Tayyip Erdoğan, the old role of the
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Religious_Affairs" title="Presidency of Religious Affairs">
         Diyanet
        </a>
       </i>
       – maintaining control over the religious sphere of Islam in Turkey – has "largely been turned on its head".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lepeska-2015_365-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lepeska-2015-365">
         [363]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Now greatly increased in size, the
       <i>
        Diyanet
       </i>
       promotes a certain type of conservative (Hanafi Sunni) Islam inside Turkey, issuing
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Fatwa" title="Fatwa">
         fetva
        </a>
       </i>
       which disapprove activities such as "feeding dogs at home, celebrating the western New Year, lotteries, and tattoos";
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rise_366-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-rise-366">
         [364]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and projecting this "Turkish Islam"
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lepeska-2015_365-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Lepeska-2015-365">
         [363]
        </a>
       </sup>
       abroad.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-al-monitor-29-4-16_367-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-al-monitor-29-4-16-367">
         [365]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Academics suggest the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alevi" title="Alevi">
        Alevi
       </a>
       population may be from 15 to 20 million, while the Alevi-Bektaşi Federation claims that there are around 25 million
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-usstate_368-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-usstate-368">
         [366]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-refworld.org1_369-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-refworld.org1-369">
         [367]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and according to
       <a href="/wiki/Aksiyon" title="Aksiyon">
        Aksiyon
       </a>
       magazine, the number of
       <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">
        Shiite
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Twelver" title="Twelver">
        Twelvers
       </a>
       (excluding Alevis) is 3 million (4.2 percent).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-caferi_370-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-caferi-370">
         [368]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under the Sunni Islamist government of the Justice and Development Party (AKP) and Tayyip Erdoğan, an increasing discrimination against and persecution of the Alevi minority has begun.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371">
        <a href="#cite_note-371">
         [369]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372">
        <a href="#cite_note-372">
         [370]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373">
        <a href="#cite_note-373">
         [371]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to WIN-Gallup International's Global Index of Religiosity and Atheism project,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374">
        <a href="#cite_note-374">
         [372]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey is the country with most
       <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Muslim" title="Cultural Muslim">
        irreligious Muslims
       </a>
       in the Islamic world with 73% of its Muslim population. In light of an extensive PEW Global research, only 15% of Muslims in Turkey say prayers for at least one of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salat" title="Salat">
        five prayers
       </a>
       either at home or in a mosque.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375">
        <a href="#cite_note-375">
         [373]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Another PEW Report suggests that, only 7% to 13% of all Turks think that religion should have an effect on laws directly or indirectly.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376">
        <a href="#cite_note-376">
         [374]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Christianity">
        Christianity
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Turkey" title="Christianity in Turkey">
        Christianity in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_6019.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1886" data-file-width="2576" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/%C4%B0stanbul_6019.jpg/220px-%C4%B0stanbul_6019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/%C4%B0stanbul_6019.jpg/330px-%C4%B0stanbul_6019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/%C4%B0stanbul_6019.jpg/440px-%C4%B0stanbul_6019.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_6019.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_St._Stephen_Church" title="Bulgarian St. Stephen Church">
          Bulgarian St. Stephen Church
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Fatih" title="Fatih">
          Fatih
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
          Istanbul
         </a>
         , is famous for being made of prefabricated cast iron elements in the neo-Gothic style.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
        Christianity
       </a>
       has a long history in present-day Turkey, which is the birthplace of numerous Christian
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelve_apostles" title="Twelve apostles">
        Apostles
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">
        Saints
       </a>
       , such as
       <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">
        Paul
       </a>
       of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tarsus_(city)" title="Tarsus (city)">
        Tarsus
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Saint_Timothy" title="Saint Timothy">
        Timothy
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Saint_Nicholas" title="Saint Nicholas">
        Nicholas
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Myra" title="Myra">
        Myra
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Polycarp" title="Polycarp">
        Polycarp
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">
        Smyrna
       </a>
       and many others.
       <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">
        Saint Peter
       </a>
       founded
       <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Peter" title="Church of Saint Peter">
        one of the first churches
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">
        Antioch
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Antakya" title="Antakya">
        Antakya
       </a>
       ), the location of which is regarded by tradition as the spot where he first preached the
       <a href="/wiki/Gospel" title="Gospel">
        Gospel
       </a>
       , and where the followers of
       <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">
        Jesus
       </a>
       were called
       <i>
        Christians
       </i>
       for the first time in history. The
       <a href="/wiki/House_of_the_Virgin_Mary" title="House of the Virgin Mary">
        house
       </a>
       where
       <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">
        Virgin Mary
       </a>
       lived the final days of her life until her
       <a href="/wiki/Assumption_of_Mary" title="Assumption of Mary">
        Assumption
       </a>
       (according to
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
        Catholic
       </a>
       doctrine) or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dormition" title="Dormition">
        Dormition
       </a>
       (according to
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
        Orthodox
       </a>
       belief),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377">
        <a href="#cite_note-377">
         [375]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378">
        <a href="#cite_note-378">
         [376]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_St._John" title="Basilica of St. John">
        tomb
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/John_the_Apostle" title="John the Apostle">
        John the Apostle
       </a>
       who accompanied her during the voyage to Anatolia after the
       <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">
        crucifixion of Jesus
       </a>
       , are in
       <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">
        Ephesus
       </a>
       . The cave churches in
       <a href="/wiki/Cappadocia" title="Cappadocia">
        Cappadocia
       </a>
       were among the hiding places of early Christians during the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-Christian_policies_in_the_Roman_Empire" title="Anti-Christian policies in the Roman Empire">
        persecutions
       </a>
       against them. The
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
        Eastern Orthodox Church
       </a>
       has been
       <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">
        headquartered in Constantinople (Istanbul)
       </a>
       since the
       <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Constantinople" title="First Council of Constantinople">
        First Council of Constantinople
       </a>
       in 381 AD.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rusch2013_379-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Rusch2013-379">
         [377]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FahlbuschBromiley2001_380-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FahlbuschBromiley2001-380">
         [378]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Two of the five major
       <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_see" title="Episcopal see">
        episcopal sees
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Pentarchy" title="Pentarchy">
        Pentarchy
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">
        Constantinople
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church_of_Antioch" title="Greek Orthodox Church of Antioch">
        Antioch
       </a>
       ) instituted by
       <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">
        Justinian the Great
       </a>
       in 531 AD
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381">
        <a href="#cite_note-381">
         [379]
        </a>
       </sup>
       were located in present-day Turkey during the
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">
        Byzantine
       </a>
       period.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382">
        <a href="#cite_note-382">
         [380]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The percentage of Christians in Turkey fell from 17.5% (19% non-Muslim) in a population of 16 million (or perhaps as high as 25% of the population of 16 million in 1914 to 2.5% percent in 1927,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383">
        <a href="#cite_note-383">
         [381]
        </a>
       </sup>
       due to events which had a significant impact on the country's demographic structure, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide" title="Armenian Genocide">
        Armenian Genocide
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">
        population exchange between Greece and Turkey
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384">
        <a href="#cite_note-384">
         [382]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Christian_emigration" title="Christian emigration">
        emigration of Christians
       </a>
       that actually began in the late 19th century and gained pace in the first quarter of the 20th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385">
        <a href="#cite_note-385">
         [383]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Varl%C4%B1k_Vergisi" title="Varlık Vergisi">
        Wealth Tax
       </a>
       on non-Muslims in 1942, the emigration of a portion of Turkish Jews to Israel after 1948, and the ongoing
       <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">
        Cyprus dispute
       </a>
       which damaged the relations between Turks and Greeks (culminating in the
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_pogrom" title="Istanbul pogrom">
        Istanbul pogrom
       </a>
       of 6–7 September 1955) were other important events that contributed to the decline of Turkey's non-Muslim population. The discrepancy of 7.5% between the official figure of 17% andf 25% is very possibly possible an undercount: 1.8 million Armenians instead of 1.25 (Enver Pasha stated the number of Armenians was underestimated by 30% in the census of whom 500,000 to 1.1 million were killed), 2.250 million Greeks instead of 1.75 (650,000 Thrace and Constantinople, 550,000 Pontic (350,000 killed), 980,00 Anatolia and Cappadocia 60,000 (400,000 killed); even listed in the census the 375,000 Syriac/Assyrian Christians living in SE Turkey of whom 275,000 were killed) for a total of 4.4 million Christians in a population of 17.4 million or 25.28% or slightly less since 100,000 Greeks had left after the Balkan Wars and before WW1. Etimates of the numbers of Greeks range from 550,000 to 900,000.
      </p>
      <p>
       Today there are more than 120,000 people of different
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_denominations" title="Christian denominations">
        Christian denominations
       </a>
       , representing less than 0.2 percent of Turkey's population,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia-rel_386-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cia-rel-386">
         [384]
        </a>
       </sup>
       including an estimated 80,000
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox" title="Oriental Orthodox">
        Oriental Orthodox
       </a>
       , 35,000
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
        Roman Catholics
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-catho_387-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-catho-387">
         [385]
        </a>
       </sup>
       18,000
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antiochian_Greeks" title="Antiochian Greeks">
        Antiochian Greeks
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388">
        <a href="#cite_note-388">
         [386]
        </a>
       </sup>
       5,000
       <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">
        Greek Orthodox
       </a>
       , and smaller numbers of
       <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">
        Protestants
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-christiancentury.org_389-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-christiancentury.org-389">
         [387]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Currently there are 236 churches open for worship in Turkey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390">
        <a href="#cite_note-390">
         [388]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Judaism">
        Judaism
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judaism_in_Turkey" title="Judaism in Turkey">
        Judaism in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GrandSynagogueEdirne_(2).JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2328" data-file-width="3618" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/GrandSynagogueEdirne_%282%29.JPG/220px-GrandSynagogueEdirne_%282%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/GrandSynagogueEdirne_%282%29.JPG/330px-GrandSynagogueEdirne_%282%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/GrandSynagogueEdirne_%282%29.JPG/440px-GrandSynagogueEdirne_%282%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GrandSynagogueEdirne_(2).JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Grand_Synagogue_of_Edirne" title="Grand Synagogue of Edirne">
          Grand Synagogue
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">
          Edirne
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The history of
       <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">
        Judaism
       </a>
       in Turkey goes back to the
       <a href="/wiki/Romaniote_Jews" title="Romaniote Jews">
        Romaniote Jews of Anatolia
       </a>
       who have been present since at least the 5th century BC. They built ancient places of worship such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Sardis_Synagogue" title="Sardis Synagogue">
        Sardis Synagogue
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">
        Lydia
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Priene_Synagogue" title="Priene Synagogue">
        Priene Synagogue
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Ionia" title="Ionia">
        Ionia
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">
        Sephardi Jews
       </a>
       who were
       <a href="/wiki/Alhambra_Decree" title="Alhambra Decree">
        expelled from
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">
        the Iberian peninsula
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Naples" title="Kingdom of Naples">
        and southern Italy
       </a>
       under the control of the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
        Spanish Empire
       </a>
       were welcomed into the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       between the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Inquisition" title="Spanish Inquisition">
        late-15th
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Italy#Expulsion_from_Naples" title="History of the Jews in Italy">
        mid-16th
       </a>
       centuries. Despite
       <a href="/wiki/Aliyah" title="Aliyah">
        emigration during the 20th century
       </a>
       , modern-day Turkey continues to have a small Jewish population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-science.co.il_391-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-science.co.il-391">
         [389]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At present, there are around 26,000
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Turkey" title="History of the Jews in Turkey">
        Jews in Turkey
       </a>
       , the vast majority of whom are Sephardi.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392">
        <a href="#cite_note-392">
         [390]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Agnosticism_and_atheism">
        Agnosticism and atheism
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       According to a 2010
       <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">
        Eurobarometer
       </a>
       poll 94% of Turks believed in God while only 1% did not. This indicates that 5% of the population are
       <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">
        agnostic
       </a>
       with another 1% being explicitly
       <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">
        atheist
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393">
        <a href="#cite_note-393">
         [391]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, according to another poll by KONDA the percentage of atheism is 2.9%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-human.nl_394-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-human.nl-394">
         [392]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <i>
        Atheism Association of Turkey
       </i>
       , the first official atheist organisation in Balkans, Caucasus and Middle East, was founded in 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blogs.lse.ac.uk1_359-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-blogs.lse.ac.uk1-359">
         [358]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishatheist.net1_395-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-turkishatheist.net1-395">
         [393]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Recent polls suggest that 4.5 million people were irreligious in 2013. The same data also suggests that 85% of all irreligious people are younger than 35.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396">
        <a href="#cite_note-396">
         [394]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Turkey" title="Education in Turkey">
        Education in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_high_schools_in_Turkey" title="List of high schools in Turkey">
        List of high schools in Turkey
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Turkey" title="List of universities in Turkey">
        List of universities in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008b.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008b.JPG/220px-Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008b.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008b.JPG/330px-Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008b.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008b.JPG/440px-Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008b.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_University_campus_March_2008b.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">
          Istanbul University
         </a>
         was founded in 1453 as a
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_technology" title="Institute of technology">
           Darülfünûn
          </a>
         </i>
         . On 1 August 1933 it was reorganised and became the Republic's first university.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-istanbuluniversity_397-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-istanbuluniversity-397">
           [395]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Education_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Education (Turkey)">
        Ministry of National Education
       </a>
       is responsible for pre-tertiary education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wesed_398-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-wesed-398">
         [396]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This is compulsory and lasts twelve years: four years each of primary school, middle school and high school.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-peg_399-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nyt-peg-399">
         [397]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Less than half of 25- to 34-year-old Turks have completed at least
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_school" title="High school">
        high school
       </a>
       , compared with an
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       average of over 80 percent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecdind_400-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-oecdind-400">
         [398]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Basic education in Turkey is considered to lag behind other OECD countries, with significant differences between high and low performers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WBedu_401-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WBedu-401">
         [399]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey is ranked 32nd out of 34 in the OECD's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PISA" title="PISA">
        PISA
       </a>
       study.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-peg_399-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-nyt-peg-399">
         [397]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Access to high-quality school heavily depends on the performance in the secondary school entrance exams, to the point that some students begin taking private tutoring classes when they are 10 years old.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WBedu_401-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-WBedu-401">
         [399]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The overall adult literacy rate in 2011 was 94.1 percent; 97.9 percent for males and 90.3 percent for females.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unescolit_402-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-unescolit-402">
         [400]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As of 2017, there are 190
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universities_in_Turkey" title="Universities in Turkey">
        universities in Turkey
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403">
        <a href="#cite_note-403">
         [401]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Entry to higher education depends on the
       <a href="/wiki/Student_Selection_and_Placement_System" title="Student Selection and Placement System">
        Student Selection and Placement System
       </a>
       (ÖSYS). In 2008, the quota of admitted students was 600,000, compared to 1,700,000 who took the higher education exam in 2007.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Group2009_404-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Group2009-404">
         [402]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Except for the Open Education Faculties (AÖF) at
       <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_University" title="Anadolu University">
        Anadolu
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">
        Istanbul
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_University" title="Atatürk University">
        Atatürk University
       </a>
       ; entrance is regulated by the national ÖSYS examination, after which high school graduates are assigned to universities according to their performance.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405">
        <a href="#cite_note-405">
         [403]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the 2012–2013
       <a href="/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings" title="Times Higher Education World University Rankings">
        Times Higher Education World University Rankings
       </a>
       , the top university in Turkey is
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_East_Technical_University" title="Middle East Technical University">
        Middle East Technical University
       </a>
       (in the 201–225 rank range), followed by
       <a href="/wiki/Bilkent_University" title="Bilkent University">
        Bilkent University
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ko%C3%A7_University" title="Koç University">
        Koç University
       </a>
       (both in the 226–250 range),
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">
        Istanbul Technical University
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_University" title="Boğaziçi University">
        Boğaziçi University
       </a>
       (in the 276–300 bracket).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-therank_406-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-therank-406">
         [404]
        </a>
       </sup>
       All state and private universities are under the control of the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Higher_Education_(Turkey)" title="Council of Higher Education (Turkey)">
        Higher Education Board
       </a>
       (YÖK), whose head is appointed by the President of Turkey; executive order 676 of October 2016 has created a system where in addition the President directly appoints all rectors of all state and private universities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407">
        <a href="#cite_note-407">
         [405]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey is a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Higher_Education_Area" title="European Higher Education Area">
        European Higher Education Area
       </a>
       and actively participates in the
       <a href="/wiki/Bologna_Process" title="Bologna Process">
        Bologna Process
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408">
        <a href="#cite_note-408">
         [406]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2016 the Skills Matter survey conducted by OECD found the levels of numeracy and literacy in the adult population of Turkey at rank 30 of the 33 OECD countries surveyed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409">
        <a href="#cite_note-409">
         [407]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2017 the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theory_of_evolution" title="Theory of evolution">
        theory of evolution
       </a>
       was removed from the national curriculum in favour of teaching on the concept of jihad.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410">
        <a href="#cite_note-410">
         [408]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">
        Healthcare
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Turkey" title="Health care in Turkey">
        Health care in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_hospitals_in_Turkey" title="List of hospitals in Turkey">
        List of hospitals in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Haydarpasa_campus_general.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="387" data-file-width="1204" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Haydarpasa_campus_general.jpg/300px-Haydarpasa_campus_general.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Haydarpasa_campus_general.jpg/450px-Haydarpasa_campus_general.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Haydarpasa_campus_general.jpg/600px-Haydarpasa_campus_general.jpg 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Haydarpasa_campus_general.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Imperial College of Medicine, currently the Haydarpaşa campus of
         <a href="/wiki/Marmara_University" title="Marmara University">
          Marmara University
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Health care in Turkey used to be dominated by a centralised state system run by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of Health (Turkey)">
        Ministry of Health
       </a>
       . In 2003, the government introduced a sweeping health reform programme aimed at increasing the ratio of private to state health provision and making healthcare available to a larger share of the population.
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Statistical_Institute" title="Turkish Statistical Institute">
        Turkish Statistical Institute
       </a>
       announced that 76.3 billion
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_lira" title="Turkish lira">
        TL
       </a>
       was spent for healthcare in 2012; 79.6 percent of which was covered by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sosyal_G%C3%BCvenlik_Kurumu" title="Sosyal Güvenlik Kurumu">
        Social Security Institution
       </a>
       and 15.4 percent of which was paid directly by the patients.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411">
        <a href="#cite_note-411">
         [409]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2012, there were 29,960 medical institutions in Turkey,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TUIKmedical_412-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TUIKmedical-412">
         [410]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and on average one doctor per 583 people
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413">
        <a href="#cite_note-413">
         [411]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 2.65 beds per 1000 people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TUIKmedical_412-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TUIKmedical-412">
         [410]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2015,
       <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
        life expectancy
       </a>
       was 72.6 years for men and 78.9 for women, with an overall average of 75.8.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414">
        <a href="#cite_note-414">
         [412]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Turkey" title="Culture of Turkey">
        Culture of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arts_in_Turkey" title="Arts in Turkey">
        Arts in Turkey
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folklore" title="Turkish folklore">
        Turkish folklore
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festivals_in_Turkey" title="Festivals in Turkey">
        Festivals in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Whirlingdervishes.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="707" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/220px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/330px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Whirlingdervishes.JPG/440px-Whirlingdervishes.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Whirlingdervishes.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Whirling Dervishes of the
         <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">
          Sufi
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">
          Mevlevi Order
         </a>
         , founded by the followers of the 13th-century Sufi
         <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">
          mystic
         </a>
         and poet
         <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">
          Rumi
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">
          Konya
         </a>
         , during a
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sema" title="Sema">
          Sema
         </a>
         . The ceremony is one of the 11 elements of Turkey on the
         <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">
          UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unesco1_415-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-unesco1-415">
           [413]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Turkey has a very diverse culture that is a blend of various elements of the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">
        Turkic
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
        Anatolian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Culture of the Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman
       </a>
       (which was itself a continuation of both
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greco-Roman" title="Greco-Roman">
        Greco-Roman
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">
        Islamic
       </a>
       cultures) and
       <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">
        Western culture
       </a>
       and traditions, which started with the
       <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">
        Westernisation of the Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       and still continues today. This mix originally began as a result of the encounter of Turks and their culture with those of the peoples who were in their path during
       <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">
        their migration
       </a>
       from Central Asia to the West.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_culture_416-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-416">
         [414]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417">
        <a href="#cite_note-417">
         [415]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkish culture is a product of efforts to be a "modern" Western state, while maintaining traditional religious and historical values.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_culture_416-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-416">
         [414]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">
        Visual arts
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_painting" title="Turkish painting">
        Turkish painting
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0znik_pottery" title="İznik pottery">
        İznik pottery
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_carpet" title="Turkish carpet">
        Turkish carpet
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_miniature" title="Turkish miniature">
        Turkish miniature
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_illumination" title="Turkish illumination">
        Turkish illumination
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:299px;max-width:299px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:164px;max-width:164px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3527" data-file-width="2419" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/162px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/243px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/324px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="162"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:131px;max-width:131px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3659" data-file-width="2004" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/129px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/194px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/258px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_The_Tortoise_Trainer_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="129"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
         <i>
          Two Musician Girls
         </i>
         (left) and
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/The_Tortoise_Trainer" title="The Tortoise Trainer">
           The Tortoise Trainer
          </a>
         </i>
         (right) by
         <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">
          Osman Hamdi Bey
         </a>
         , at the
         <a href="/wiki/Pera_Museum" title="Pera Museum">
          Pera Museum
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Turkish_painters" title="List of Turkish painters">
        Turkish painting
       </a>
       , in the Western sense, developed actively starting from the mid 19th century. The very first painting lessons were scheduled at what is now the
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">
        Istanbul Technical University
       </a>
       (then the
       <i>
        Imperial Military Engineering School
       </i>
       ) in 1793, mostly for technical purposes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarriOhta1999_418-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-HarriOhta1999-418">
         [416]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the late 19th century, human figure in the Western sense was being established in Turkish painting, especially with
       <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">
        Osman Hamdi Bey
       </a>
       . Impressionism, among the contemporary trends, appeared later on with
       <a href="/wiki/Halil_Pasha_(painter)" title="Halil Pasha (painter)">
        Halil Pasha
       </a>
       . The young Turkish artists sent to Europe in 1926 came back inspired by contemporary trends such as Fauvism, Cubism and even Expressionism, still very influential in Europe. The later "Group D" of artists led by
       <a href="/wiki/Abidin_Dino" title="Abidin Dino">
        Abidin Dino
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cemal_Tollu" title="Cemal Tollu">
        Cemal Tollu
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fikret_Mualla" title="Fikret Mualla">
        Fikret Mualla
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Princess_Fahrelnissa_Zeid" title="Princess Fahrelnissa Zeid">
        Fahrünnisa Zeid
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bedri_Rahmi_Eyuboglu" title="Bedri Rahmi Eyuboglu">
        Bedri Rahmi Eyüboğlu
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Adnan_Coker" title="Adnan Coker">
        Adnan Çoker
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Burhan_Do%C4%9Fan%C3%A7ay" title="Burhan Doğançay">
        Burhan Doğançay
       </a>
       introduced some trends that had lasted in the West for more than three decades. Other important movements in Turkish painting were the "Yeniler Grubu" (The Newcomers Group) of the late 1930s; the "On'lar Grubu" (Group of Ten) of the 1940s; the "Yeni Dal Grubu" (New Branch Group) of the 1950s; and the "Siyah Kalem Grubu" (Black Pen Group) of the 1960s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkresmi.com_419-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-turkresmi.com-419">
         [417]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="806" data-file-width="600" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png/170px-Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png/255px-Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png/340px-Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seljuk_Carpet_Fragment_13th_Century..png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A 13th century
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_carpet" title="Turkish carpet">
          Turkish carpet
         </a>
         from the
         <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">
          Anatolian Seljuk Sultanate
         </a>
         period, originally at the
         <a href="/wiki/Al%C3%A2eddin_Mosque" title="Alâeddin Mosque">
          Alâeddin Mosque
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">
          Konya
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420">
          <a href="#cite_note-420">
           [418]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_carpet" title="Turkish carpet">
        Carpet weaving
       </a>
       represents a traditional art, dating back to pre-Islamic times. During its long history, the art and craft of the woven carpet has integrated different cultural traditions. Traces of Byzantine design can be detected,
       <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">
        Turkic peoples
       </a>
       migrating from Central Asia, as well as Armenian people, Caucasian and Kurdic tribes either living in, or migrating to Anatolia, brought with them their traditional designs. The arrival of Islam and the development of the
       <a href="/wiki/Islamic_art" title="Islamic art">
        Islamic art
       </a>
       also influenced Turkish carpet design. The history of its designs, motifs and ornaments thus reflects the political and ethnic history and diversity of the area of Asia minor. However, scientific attempts were unsuccessful, as yet, to attribute a particular design to a specific ethnic, regional, or even nomadic versus village tradition.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421">
        <a href="#cite_note-421">
         [419]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_miniature" title="Turkish miniature">
        Turkish miniature
       </a>
       is an art form, which can be linked to the Persian miniature tradition, as well as strong Chinese artistic influences. The words taswir or nakish were used to define the art of miniature painting in Ottoman Turkish. The studios the artists worked in were called Nakkashanes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-miniature1_422-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-miniature1-422">
         [420]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The miniatures were usually not signed, perhaps because of the rejection of individualism, but also because the works were not created entirely by one person; the head painter designed the composition of the scene, and his apprentices drew the contours (which were called tahrir) with black or colored ink and then painted the miniature without creating an illusion of third dimension. The head painter, and much more often the scribe of the text, were indeed named and depicted in some of the manuscripts. The understanding of perspective was different from that of the nearby European Renaissance painting tradition, and the scene depicted often included different time periods and spaces in one picture. They followed closely the context of the book they were included in, resembling more illustrations rather than standalone works of art.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org2_423-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org2-423">
         [421]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The earliest examples of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_paper_marbling" title="Turkish paper marbling">
        Turkish paper marbling
       </a>
       are thought to be a copy of the Hâlnâme by the poet Arifî. The text of this manuscript was rendered in a delicate cut paper découpage calligraphy by Mehmed bin Gazanfer and completed in 1540, and features many marbled and decorative paper borders. One early master by the name of Şebek is mentioned posthumously in the earliest Ottoman text on the art known as the Tertib-i Risâle-i Ebrî, which is dated based on internal evidence to after 1615. Several recipes in the text are accredited to this master. Another famous 18th-century master by the name of Hatip Mehmed Efendi (died 1773) is accredited with developing motifs and perhaps early floral designs, although evidence from India appears to contradict some of these claims. Despite this, marbled motifs are commonly referred to as "Hatip" designs in Turkey today.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org3_424-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org3-424">
         [422]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_theatre">
        Literature and theatre
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">
        Turkish literature
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Turkey" title="Theatre of Turkey">
        Theatre of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tevfik_Fikret2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="786" data-file-width="583" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7a/Tevfik_Fikret2.jpg/175px-Tevfik_Fikret2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7a/Tevfik_Fikret2.jpg/263px-Tevfik_Fikret2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7a/Tevfik_Fikret2.jpg/350px-Tevfik_Fikret2.jpg 2x" width="175"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tevfik_Fikret2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Tevfik_Fikret" title="Tevfik Fikret">
          Tevfik Fikret
         </a>
         is considered the founder of the modern school of
         <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature#Early_20th-century_Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">
          Turkish poetry
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425">
          <a href="#cite_note-425">
           [423]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">
        Turkish literature
       </a>
       is a mix of cultural influences. Interaction between the Ottoman Empire and the Islamic world along with Europe contributed to a blend of Turkic, Islamic and European traditions in modern-day Turkish music and literary arts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ottomus_426-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ottomus-426">
         [424]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">
        Turkish literature
       </a>
       was heavily influenced by
       <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">
        Persian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">
        Arabic literature
       </a>
       during most of the Ottoman era. The
       <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">
        Tanzimat
       </a>
       reforms introduced previously unknown Western genres, primarily the novel and the short story. Many of the writers in the Tanzimat period wrote in several genres simultaneously: for instance, the poet
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Namik_Kemal" title="Namik Kemal">
        Nâmık Kemal
       </a>
       also wrote the important 1876 novel
       <i>
        İntibâh
       </i>
       (Awakening), while the journalist
       <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0brahim_%C5%9Einasi" title="İbrahim Şinasi">
        Şinasi
       </a>
       is noted for writing, in 1860, the first modern Turkish play, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One_act_play" title="One act play">
        one-act
       </a>
       comedy "
       <i>
        Şair Evlenmesi
       </i>
       " (The Poet's Marriage). Most of the roots of modern Turkish literature were formed between the years 1896 and 1923. Broadly, there were three primary literary movements during this period: the
       <i>
        Edebiyat-ı Cedîde
       </i>
       (New Literature) movement; the
       <i>
        Fecr-i Âtî
       </i>
       (Dawn of the Future) movement; and the
       <i>
        Millî Edebiyat
       </i>
       (National Literature) movement. The first radical step of innovation in 20th century Turkish poetry was taken by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/N%C3%A2z%C4%B1m_Hikmet_Ran" title="Nâzım Hikmet Ran">
        Nâzım Hikmet
       </a>
       , who introduced the
       <a href="/wiki/Free_verse" title="Free verse">
        free verse
       </a>
       style. Another revolution in Turkish poetry came about in 1941 with the
       <a href="/wiki/Garip" title="Garip">
        Garip
       </a>
       movement led by
       <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Veli_Kan%C4%B1k" title="Orhan Veli Kanık">
        Orhan Veli
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Oktay_R%C4%B1fat_Horozcu" title="Oktay Rıfat Horozcu">
        Oktay Rıfat
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Melih_Cevdet_Anday" title="Melih Cevdet Anday">
        Melih Cevdet
       </a>
       . The mix of cultural influences in Turkey is dramatised, for example, in the form of the "new symbols of the clash and interlacing of cultures" enacted in the novels of
       <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Pamuk" title="Orhan Pamuk">
        Orhan Pamuk
       </a>
       , recipient of the 2006
       <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">
        Nobel Prize in Literature
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427">
        <a href="#cite_note-427">
         [425]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IOM_Ik%C4%B1nc%C4%B1_Abdulhamit_Donemi.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="450" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/IOM_Ik%C4%B1nc%C4%B1_Abdulhamit_Donemi.jpg/150px-IOM_Ik%C4%B1nc%C4%B1_Abdulhamit_Donemi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/IOM_Ik%C4%B1nc%C4%B1_Abdulhamit_Donemi.jpg/225px-IOM_Ik%C4%B1nc%C4%B1_Abdulhamit_Donemi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/IOM_Ik%C4%B1nc%C4%B1_Abdulhamit_Donemi.jpg/300px-IOM_Ik%C4%B1nc%C4%B1_Abdulhamit_Donemi.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IOM_Ik%C4%B1nc%C4%B1_Abdulhamit_Donemi.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Characters of
         <a href="/wiki/Karag%C3%B6z_and_Hacivat" title="Karagöz and Hacivat">
          Karagöz and Hacivat
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The origin of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_theatre" title="Turkish theatre">
        Turkish theatre
       </a>
       dates back thousands of years to ancient pagan rituals. The dances, music and songs performed during the rituals of the inhabitants of Anatolia millennia ago are the elements from which the first shows originated. These rituals later became theatrical shows. In the 10th century, a blend of traditions occurred between the Seljuk Turks and those of the inhabitants of Anatolia. The interaction between the various tribal societies paved the way for new plays. After the Tanzimat (Reformation) period, characters in Turkish theatre were modernized and plays were performed on European-style stages with the actors wearing European costumes. Following the declaration of the second Constitutional Monarchy in 1908, theatrical activities increased and social problems began to be reflected in the theatre as well as in historical plays. A theatrical conservatoire, Darülbedayi-i Osmani, was established in Istanbul in 1914. During the years of chaos and war, the Darülbedayi-i Osmani continued its activities and attracted the younger generation. Turkish playwrights emerged. Some wrote on romantic subjects, others were interested in social problems and still others dealt with nationalistic themes. There were even those who wrote musicals. In time, Turkish ladies began to appear on stage and this was indeed a revolution of the time, since female roles had only been played by actresses who were members of Turkey’s ethnic minorities. Today, theatre acts are performed by numerous private theatre companies and subsidized companies such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Theatres" title="Turkish State Theatres">
        Turkish State Theatres
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org4_428-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org4-428">
         [426]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">
        Music and dance
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_dance" title="Turkish dance">
        Turkish dance
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">
        Music of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_classical_music" title="Turkish classical music">
        Turkish classical music
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folk_music" title="Turkish folk music">
        Turkish folk music
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_music_(style)" title="Turkish music (style)">
        Turkish music (style)
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:102px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_Baglama_-_ba%C4%9Flama_(3141802804).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3635" data-file-width="1734" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Turkish_Baglama_-_ba%C4%9Flama_%283141802804%29.jpg/100px-Turkish_Baglama_-_ba%C4%9Flama_%283141802804%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Turkish_Baglama_-_ba%C4%9Flama_%283141802804%29.jpg/150px-Turkish_Baglama_-_ba%C4%9Flama_%283141802804%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Turkish_Baglama_-_ba%C4%9Flama_%283141802804%29.jpg/200px-Turkish_Baglama_-_ba%C4%9Flama_%283141802804%29.jpg 2x" width="100"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_Baglama_-_ba%C4%9Flama_(3141802804).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Ba%C4%9Flama" title="Bağlama">
           Bağlama
          </a>
         </i>
         , a traditional stringed musical instrument.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">
        Music of Turkey
       </a>
       includes mainly
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkic_culture" title="Turkic culture">
        Turkic
       </a>
       elements as well as partial influences ranging from
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Central_Asia" title="Music of Central Asia">
        Central Asian folk music
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Arabic_music" title="Arabic music">
        Arabic music
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greek_music" title="Greek music">
        Greek music
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_music" title="Ottoman music">
        Ottoman music
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Persian_traditional_music" title="Persian traditional music">
        Persian music
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Music_of_Southeastern_Europe" title="Music of Southeastern Europe">
        Balkan music
       </a>
       , as well as references to more modern European and
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States" title="Music of the United States">
        American
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">
        popular music
       </a>
       . The roots of traditional music in Turkey span across centuries to a time when the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuk_Turks" title="Seljuk Turks">
        Seljuk Turks
       </a>
       migrated to
       <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">
        Anatolia
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persia" title="Persia">
        Persia
       </a>
       in the 11th century and contains elements of both Turkic and pre-Turkic influences. Much of its modern popular music can trace its roots to the emergence in the early 1930s drive for
       <a href="/wiki/Westernization" title="Westernization">
        Westernization
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-soundsofanatolia_429-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-soundsofanatolia-429">
         [427]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
