       With the assimilation of immigrants from various regions the diversity of musical genres and musical instrumentation also expanded. Turkey has also seen documented folk music and recorded popular music produced in the ethnic styles of
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Greece" title="Music of Greece">
        Greek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Armenia" title="Music of Armenia">
        Armenian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Albania" title="Music of Albania">
        Albanian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Poland" title="Music of Poland">
        Polish
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish">
        Jewish
       </a>
       communities, among others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lesartsturcs_430-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-lesartsturcs-430">
         [428]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="250" data-file-width="250" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/15/Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o.jpg/150px-Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/15/Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o.jpg/225px-Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/15/Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o" title="Barış Manço">
          Barış Manço
         </a>
         was among the founders of the genre
         <a href="/wiki/Rock_music_in_Turkey" title="Rock music in Turkey">
          Anatolian rock
         </a>
         in the 1960s, which combines rock music with Anatolian folk tunes.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Many Turkish cities and towns have vibrant local music scenes which, in turn, support a number of regional musical styles. Despite this however, western-style music styles like
       <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">
        pop music
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Kanto_(music)" title="Kanto (music)">
        kanto
       </a>
       lost popularity to
       <a href="/wiki/Arabesque" title="Arabesque">
        arabesque
       </a>
       in the late 70s and 80s. It became popular again by the beginning of the 1990s, as a result of an opening economy and society. With the support of
       <a href="/wiki/Sezen_Aksu" title="Sezen Aksu">
        Sezen Aksu
       </a>
       , the resurging popularity of pop music gave rise to several international Turkish pop stars such as
       <a href="/wiki/Tarkan_(singer)" title="Tarkan (singer)">
        Tarkan
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sertab_Erener" title="Sertab Erener">
        Sertab Erener
       </a>
       . The late 1990s also saw an emergence of underground music producing alternative
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_rock_music" title="Turkish rock music">
        Turkish rock
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Electronica" title="Electronica">
        electronica
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_hip_hop" title="Turkish hip hop">
        hip-hop
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">
        rap
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Dance_music" title="Dance music">
        dance music
       </a>
       in opposition to the mainstream corporate
       <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">
        pop
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabesque_music" title="Arabesque music">
        arabesque
       </a>
       genres, which many believe have become too commercial.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-musicscene_431-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-musicscene-431">
         [429]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Turkey has a
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_dance" title="Turkish dance">
        diverse folkloric dance
       </a>
       culture.
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Hora_(dance)" title="Hora (dance)">
         Hora
        </a>
       </i>
       is performed in
       <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">
        East Thrace
       </a>
       ;
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Zeybek_dance" title="Zeybek dance">
         Zeybek
        </a>
       </i>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Region" title="Aegean Region">
        Aegean Region
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" title="Marmara Region">
        Southern Marmara
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">
        East-Central Anatolia Region
       </a>
       ;
       <i>
        Teke
       </i>
       in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" title="Mediterranean Region">
        Western Mediterranean Region
       </a>
       ;
       <i>
        Kaşık Oyunları
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kar%C5%9F%C4%B1lama" title="Karşılama">
         Karşılama
        </a>
       </i>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">
        West-Central Anatolia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">
        Western Black Sea Region
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" title="Marmara Region">
        Southern Marmara Region
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" title="Mediterranean Region">
        Eastern Mediterranean Region
       </a>
       ;
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Horon" title="Horon">
         Horon
        </a>
       </i>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">
        Central and Eastern Black Sea Region
       </a>
       ;
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Halay" title="Halay">
         Halay
        </a>
       </i>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">
        Eastern Anatolia
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">
        Central Anatolia Region
       </a>
       ; and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Bar_(dance)" title="Bar (dance)">
         Bar
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Lezginka" title="Lezginka">
         Lezginka
        </a>
       </i>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">
        Northeastern Anatolia Region
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-.ncturkishfestival._432-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-.ncturkishfestival.-432">
         [430]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">
        Architecture
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Turkey" title="Architecture of Turkey">
        Architecture of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">
        Byzantine architecture
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_architecture" title="Seljuk architecture">
        Seljuk architecture
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">
        Ottoman architecture
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/200px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/300px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG/400px-%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk_Postane_1.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1865" data-file-width="2417" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/200px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/300px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG/400px-Ziraat_Bankas%C4%B1_5.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          The
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">
           Grand Post Office
          </a>
          (1905–1909) in Istanbul and the first
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ziraat_Bank" title="Ziraat Bank">
           Ziraat Bank
          </a>
          headquarters (1925–1929) in Ankara are among the examples of
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_National_Architectural_Movement" title="First National Architectural Movement">
           Turkish Neoclassical architecture
          </a>
          in the early 20th century.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_architecture" title="Seljuk architecture">
        architecture of the Seljuk Turks
       </a>
       combined the elements and characteristics of the
       <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Central_Asia" title="Architecture of Central Asia">
        Turkic architecture of Central Asia
       </a>
       with those of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_architecture" title="Persian architecture">
        Persian
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_architecture" title="Arab architecture">
        Arab
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Armenian_architecture" title="Armenian architecture">
        Armenian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">
        Byzantine
       </a>
       architecture. The transition from Seljuk architecture to
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">
        Ottoman architecture
       </a>
       is most visible in
       <a href="/wiki/Bursa" title="Bursa">
        Bursa
       </a>
       , which was the capital of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman State
       </a>
       between 1335 and 1413. Following the
       <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">
        Ottoman conquest of Constantinople (Istanbul)
       </a>
       in 1453, Ottoman architecture was significantly influenced by
       <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">
        Byzantine architecture
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="Topkapı Palace">
        Topkapı Palace
       </a>
       in Istanbul is one of the most famous examples of classical Ottoman architecture and was the primary residence of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_Sultan" title="Ottoman Sultan">
        Ottoman Sultans
       </a>
       for approximately 400 years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_433-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-433">
         [431]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">
        Mimar Sinan
       </a>
       (c.1489–1588) was the most important architect of the classical period in Ottoman architecture. He was the chief architect of at least 374 buildings which were constructed in various
       <a href="/wiki/Eyalet" title="Eyalet">
        provinces
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       in the 16th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434">
        <a href="#cite_note-434">
         [432]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Since the 18th century, Turkish architecture has been increasingly influenced by European styles, and this can be particularly seen in the
       <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">
        Tanzimat
       </a>
       era buildings of Istanbul like the
       <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="Dolmabahçe Palace">
        Dolmabahçe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%87%C4%B1ra%C4%9Fan_Palace" title="Çırağan Palace">
        Çırağan
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feriye_Saraylar%C4%B1" title="Feriye Sarayları">
        Feriye
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Beylerbeyi_Palace" title="Beylerbeyi Palace">
        Beylerbeyi
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace" title="Küçüksu Palace">
        Küçüksu
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ihlamur_Palace" title="Ihlamur Palace">
        Ihlamur
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1z_Palace" title="Yıldız Palace">
        Yıldız
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Palace" title="Palace">
        palaces
       </a>
       , which were all designed by members of the
       <a href="/wiki/Balyan_family" title="Balyan family">
        Balyan family
       </a>
       of Ottoman court architects.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435">
        <a href="#cite_note-435">
         [433]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Ottoman era
       <a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="Yalı">
        waterfront houses (
        <i>
         yalı
        </i>
        )
       </a>
       on the
       <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">
        Bosphorus
       </a>
       also reflect the fusion between classical Ottoman and European architectural styles during the aforementioned period. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_National_Architectural_Movement" title="First National Architectural Movement">
        First National Architectural Movement
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Birinci Ulusal Mimarlık Akımı
       </i>
       ) in the early 20th century sought to create a new architecture, which was based on motifs from Seljuk and Ottoman architecture. The movement was also labelled
       <i>
        Turkish Neoclassical
       </i>
       or the
       <i>
        National Architectural Renaissance
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-First_436-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-First-436">
         [434]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The leading architects of this movement were
       <a href="/wiki/Vedat_Tek" title="Vedat Tek">
        Vedat Tek
       </a>
       (1873–1942),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mimar_Kemaleddin_Bey" title="Mimar Kemaleddin Bey">
        Mimar Kemaleddin Bey
       </a>
       (1870–1927),
       <a href="/wiki/Arif_Hikmet_Koyuno%C4%9Flu" title="Arif Hikmet Koyunoğlu">
        Arif Hikmet Koyunoğlu
       </a>
       (1888–1982) and Giulio Mongeri (1873–1953).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkisharch_437-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-turkisharch-437">
         [435]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Notable buildings from this era are the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">
        Grand Post Office
       </a>
       in Istanbul (1905–1909),
       <a href="/wiki/Tayyare_Apartments" title="Tayyare Apartments">
        Tayyare Apartments
       </a>
       (1919–1922),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tayyare_438-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tayyare-438">
         [436]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_4th_Vak%C4%B1f_Han" title="Istanbul 4th Vakıf Han">
        Istanbul 4th Vakıf Han
       </a>
       (1911–1926),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439">
        <a href="#cite_note-439">
         [437]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/State_Art_and_Sculpture_Museum" title="State Art and Sculpture Museum">
        State Art and Sculpture Museum
       </a>
       (1927–1930),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stateart_440-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-stateart-440">
         [438]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnography_Museum_of_Ankara" title="Ethnography Museum of Ankara">
        Ethnography Museum of Ankara
       </a>
       (1925–1928),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnography_441-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ethnography-441">
         [439]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the first
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ziraat_Bank" title="Ziraat Bank">
        Ziraat Bank
       </a>
       headquarters in Ankara (1925–1929),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442">
        <a href="#cite_note-442">
         [440]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the first
       <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_%C4%B0%C5%9F_Bankas%C4%B1" title="Türkiye İş Bankası">
        Türkiye İş Bankası
       </a>
       headquarters in Ankara (1926–1929),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-işbank_443-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-işbank-443">
         [441]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bebek,_Istanbul" title="Bebek, Istanbul">
        Bebek
       </a>
       Mosque,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bebek_444-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bebek-444">
         [442]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and Kamer Hatun Mosque.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kamer_445-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-kamer-445">
         [443]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mass_446-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mass-446">
         [444]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:462px;max-width:462px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:236px;max-width:236px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="3238" data-file-width="4579" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg/234px-Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg/351px-Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg/468px-Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg 2x" width="234"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="Yalı">
            Yalı
           </a>
          </i>
          of Ahmet Afif Pasha in
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yenik%C3%B6y,_Istanbul" title="Yeniköy, Istanbul">
           Yeniköy
          </a>
          , Istanbul: one of 620 historic
          <a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="Yalı">
           waterfront houses
          </a>
          along the European and Asian shores of the
          <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">
           Bosphorus
          </a>
          strait.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:City_of_Safranbolu-111677.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/City_of_Safranbolu-111677.jpg/220px-City_of_Safranbolu-111677.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/City_of_Safranbolu-111677.jpg/330px-City_of_Safranbolu-111677.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/City_of_Safranbolu-111677.jpg/440px-City_of_Safranbolu-111677.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          The traditional houses of
          <a href="/wiki/Safranbolu" title="Safranbolu">
           Safranbolu
          </a>
          , a
          <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
           UNESCO
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
           World Heritage Site
          </a>
          since 1994, are among the renowned examples of
          <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">
           Ottoman architecture
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">
        Turkish cuisine
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">
        Ottoman cuisine
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1719" data-file-width="2510" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/220px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/330px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/440px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Turkish_coffee" title="Turkish coffee">
          Turkish coffee
         </a>
         with
         <a href="/wiki/Turkish_delight" title="Turkish delight">
          Turkish delight
         </a>
         . Turkish coffee is a
         <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">
          UNESCO-listed intangible cultural heritage
         </a>
         of
         <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">
          Turks
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447">
          <a href="#cite_note-447">
           [445]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448">
          <a href="#cite_note-448">
           [446]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Turkish cuisine is regarded as one of the most prominent in the world, its popularity is largely owed to the cultural influences of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       and partly because of its major tourism industry. It is largely the heritage of
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">
        Ottoman cuisine
       </a>
       , which can be described as a fusion and refinement of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Asian_cuisine" title="Central Asian cuisine">
        Central Asian
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caucasian_cuisine" title="Caucasian cuisine">
        Caucasian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_cuisine" title="Middle Eastern cuisine">
        Middle Eastern
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">
        Mediterranean
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Balkan_cuisine" title="Balkan cuisine">
        Balkan
       </a>
       cuisines.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449">
        <a href="#cite_note-449">
         [447]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country's position between the East and the
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
        Mediterranean Sea
       </a>
       helped the Turks gain complete control of major trade routes, and an ideal environment allowed plants and animals to flourish. Turkish cuisine was well established by the mid-1400s, the beginning of the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       's six hundred-year reign.
       <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">
        Yogurt
       </a>
       salads, fish in
       <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">
        olive oil
       </a>
       , and stuffed and wrapped vegetables became Turkish staples. The empire, eventually spanning from Austria to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Africa" title="Northern Africa">
        northern Africa
       </a>
       , used its land and water routes to import exotic ingredients from all over the world. By the end of the 16th century, the Ottoman court housed over 1,400 live-in cooks and passed laws regulating the freshness of food. Since the fall of the empire in World War I (1914–1918) and the establishment of the Turkish Republic in 1923, foreign food such as French hollandaise sauce and western fast food have made their way into the modern Turkish diet.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-foodbycountry.com_450-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-foodbycountry.com-450">
         [448]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:423px;max-width:423px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:197px;max-width:197px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Doner_kebab,_Istanbul,_Turkey.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Doner_kebab%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.JPG/195px-Doner_kebab%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Doner_kebab%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.JPG/293px-Doner_kebab%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Doner_kebab%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.JPG/390px-Doner_kebab%2C_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.JPG 2x" width="195"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/D%C3%B6ner_kebab" title="Döner kebab">
           Döner kebab
          </a>
          being sliced.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Baklava_-_Turkish_special,_80-ply.JPEG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="1542" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG/220px-Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG/330px-Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG/440px-Baklava_-_Turkish_special%2C_80-ply.JPEG 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          An 80-
          <a href="/wiki/Filo" title="Filo">
           layer
          </a>
          dough
          <a href="/wiki/Baklava" title="Baklava">
           baklava
          </a>
          .
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sports_in_Turkey" title="Sports in Turkey">
        Sports in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Turkey" title="Football in Turkey">
        Football in Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/220px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/330px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/440px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Turkey_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey national basketball team">
          Turkey
         </a>
         won the silver medal at the
         <a href="/wiki/2010_FIBA_World_Championship" title="2010 FIBA World Championship">
          2010 FIBA World Championship
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The most popular
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sports_in_Turkey" title="Sports in Turkey">
        sport in Turkey
       </a>
       is
       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
        association football
       </a>
       (soccer).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451">
        <a href="#cite_note-451">
         [449]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(football)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (football)">
        Galatasaray
       </a>
       won the
       <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Cup_Final" title="2000 UEFA Cup Final">
        UEFA Cup
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2000 UEFA Super Cup">
        UEFA Super Cup
       </a>
       in 2000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uefa.com_452-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-uefa.com-452">
         [450]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_national_football_team" title="Turkish national football team">
        Turkish national football team
       </a>
       has won the bronze medal at the
       <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">
        2002 FIFA World Cup
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/2003_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2003 FIFA Confederations Cup">
        2003 FIFA Confederations Cup
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008" title="UEFA Euro 2008">
        UEFA Euro 2008
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tff.org1_453-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tff.org1-453">
         [451]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Other mainstream sports such as
       <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">
        basketball
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">
        volleyball
       </a>
       are also popular. The
       <a href="/wiki/Turkey_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey national basketball team">
        men's national basketball team
       </a>
       won the silver medal at the
       <a href="/wiki/2010_FIBA_World_Championship" title="2010 FIBA World Championship">
        2010 FIBA World Championship
       </a>
       and at the
       <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2001" title="EuroBasket 2001">
        EuroBasket 2001
       </a>
       , which were both hosted by Turkey. The basketballing team is one of the most successful in the
       <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Mediterranean_Games" title="Basketball at the Mediterranean Games">
        Mediterranean Games
       </a>
       . Basketball club
       <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_Efes_S.K." title="Anadolu Efes S.K.">
        Anadolu Efes S.K.
       </a>
       won the
       <a href="/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_FIBA_Kora%C4%87_Cup" title="1995–96 FIBA Korać Cup">
        1995–96
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Kora%C4%87_Cup" title="FIBA Korać Cup">
        FIBA Korać Cup
       </a>
       , won silver at the
       <a href="/wiki/1992%E2%80%9393_FIBA_European_Cup" title="1992–93 FIBA European Cup">
        1992–93
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Saporta_Cup" title="FIBA Saporta Cup">
        FIBA Saporta Cup
       </a>
       , and won bronze at the
       <a href="/wiki/Euroleague_Basketball" title="Euroleague Basketball">
        Euroleague
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_SuproLeague" title="FIBA SuproLeague">
        Suproleague
       </a>
       in 2000 and 2001.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454">
        <a href="#cite_note-454">
         [452]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455">
        <a href="#cite_note-455">
         [453]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Basketball club
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_men%27s_basketball_team" title="Beşiktaş men's basketball team">
        Beşiktaş
       </a>
       won the
       <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_FIBA_EuroChallenge" title="2011–12 FIBA EuroChallenge">
        2011–12
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EuroChallenge" title="EuroChallenge">
        FIBA EuroChallenge
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fibaeurope.com1_456-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-fibaeurope.com1-456">
         [454]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(men%27s_basketball)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (men's basketball)">
        Galatasaray
       </a>
       won the
       <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Eurocup_Basketball" title="2015–16 Eurocup Basketball">
        2015–16 Eurocup
       </a>
       , while in the same season,
       <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Men%27s_Basketball" title="Fenerbahçe Men's Basketball">
        Fenerbahçe
       </a>
       won the silver medal in the
       <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Euroleague" title="2015–16 Euroleague">
        2015–16 Euroleague
       </a>
       . Fenerbahçe managed to win the gold medal in the
       <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_EuroLeague" title="2016–17 EuroLeague">
        2016–17 season
       </a>
       . The final of the
       <a href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_EuroLeague_Women" title="2013–14 EuroLeague Women">
        2013–14 EuroLeague Women
       </a>
       basketball championship was played between two Turkish teams,
       <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(women%27s_basketball)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (women's basketball)">
        Galatasaray
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Basketball" title="Fenerbahçe Women's Basketball">
        Fenerbahçe
       </a>
       , and won by Galatasaray.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fibaeurope.com2_457-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-fibaeurope.com2-457">
         [455]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Turkey_women%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey women's national basketball team">
        women's national basketball team
       </a>
       won the silver medal at the
       <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_Women_2011" title="EuroBasket Women 2011">
        EuroBasket Women 2011
       </a>
       and the bronze medal at the
       <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_Women_2013" title="EuroBasket Women 2013">
        EuroBasket Women 2013
       </a>
       . Along with the men's team the women's team is one of the most successful in the
       <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Mediterranean_Games" title="Basketball at the Mediterranean Games">
        Mediterranean Games
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_women%27s_volleyball_are_the_winners_of_the_2015_European_Games_5.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1354" data-file-width="2246" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Turkey_women%27s_volleyball_are_the_winners_of_the_2015_European_Games_5.JPG/220px-Turkey_women%27s_volleyball_are_the_winners_of_the_2015_European_Games_5.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Turkey_women%27s_volleyball_are_the_winners_of_the_2015_European_Games_5.JPG/330px-Turkey_women%27s_volleyball_are_the_winners_of_the_2015_European_Games_5.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Turkey_women%27s_volleyball_are_the_winners_of_the_2015_European_Games_5.JPG/440px-Turkey_women%27s_volleyball_are_the_winners_of_the_2015_European_Games_5.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_women%27s_volleyball_are_the_winners_of_the_2015_European_Games_5.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Turkey_women%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Turkey women's national volleyball team">
          Turkey
         </a>
         won the gold medal at the
         <a href="/wiki/2015_European_Games" title="2015 European Games">
          2015 European Games
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kenan.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="964" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Kenan.jpg/150px-Kenan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Kenan.jpg/225px-Kenan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Kenan.jpg/300px-Kenan.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kenan.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Kenan_Sofuo%C4%9Flu" title="Kenan Sofuoğlu">
          Kenan Sofuoğlu
         </a>
         won the highest number of
         <a href="/wiki/Supersport_World_Championship" title="Supersport World Championship">
          Supersport World Championship
         </a>
         titles.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Turkey_women%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Turkey women's national volleyball team">
        women's national volleyball team
       </a>
       won the gold medal at the
       <a href="/wiki/2015_European_Games" title="2015 European Games">
        2015 European Games
       </a>
       , the silver medal at the
       <a href="/wiki/2003_Women%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="2003 Women's European Volleyball Championship">
        2003 European Championship
       </a>
       , the bronze medal at the
       <a href="/wiki/2011_Women%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="2011 Women's European Volleyball Championship">
        2011 European Championship
       </a>
       , and the bronze medal at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2012_FIVB_World_Grand_Prix" title="2012 FIVB World Grand Prix">
        2012 FIVB World Grand Prix
       </a>
       . They also won multiple medals over multiple decades at the
       <a href="/wiki/Volleyball_at_the_Mediterranean_Games" title="Volleyball at the Mediterranean Games">
        Mediterranean Games
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tvf.org.tr_458-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tvf.org.tr-458">
         [456]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Women's volleyball clubs, namely
       <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Volleyball" title="Fenerbahçe Women's Volleyball">
        Fenerbahçe
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1_Istanbul" title="Eczacıbaşı Istanbul">
        Eczacıbaşı
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vak%C4%B1fbank_Spor_Kul%C3%BCb%C3%BC" title="Vakıfbank Spor Kulübü">
        Vakıfbank
       </a>
       , have won numerous European championship titles and medals.
       <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Volleyball" title="Fenerbahçe Women's Volleyball">
        Fenerbahçe
       </a>
       won the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2010_FIVB_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2010 FIVB Women's Club World Championship">
        2010 FIVB Women's Club World Championship
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="CEV Women's Champions League">
        2012 CEV Women's Champions League
       </a>
       . Representing
       <a href="/wiki/European_Volleyball_Confederation" title="European Volleyball Confederation">
        Europe
       </a>
       as the winner of the
       <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="2012–13 CEV Women's Champions League">
        2012–13 CEV Women's Champions League
       </a>
       , Vakıfbank also became the world champion by winning the
       <a href="/wiki/2013_FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2013 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">
        2013
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/2017_FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2017 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">
        2017 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fenerbahce.org.tr_459-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-fenerbahce.org.tr-459">
         [457]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eczacibasisporkulubu.org.tr_460-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-eczacibasisporkulubu.org.tr-460">
         [458]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hurriyet.com.tr1_461-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-hurriyet.com.tr1-461">
         [459]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The traditional national sport of Turkey has been
       <a href="/wiki/Oil_wrestling" title="Oil wrestling">
        yağlı güreş
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        oil wrestling
       </i>
       ) since Ottoman times.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462">
        <a href="#cite_note-462">
         [460]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">
        Edirne
       </a>
       has hosted the annual
       <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1rkp%C4%B1nar" title="Kırkpınar">
        Kırkpınar
       </a>
       oiled wrestling tournament since 1346, making it the oldest sporting competition in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463">
        <a href="#cite_note-463">
         [461]
        </a>
       </sup>
       International wrestling styles governed by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_Associated_Wrestling_Styles" title="International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles">
        FILA
       </a>
       such as
       <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_wrestling" title="Freestyle wrestling">
        freestyle wrestling
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_wrestling" title="Greco-Roman wrestling">
        Greco-Roman wrestling
       </a>
       are also popular, with many European, World and Olympic championship titles won by Turkish wrestlers both individually and as a national team.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464">
        <a href="#cite_note-464">
         [462]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_cinema">
        Media and cinema
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_in_Turkey" title="Media in Turkey">
        Media in Turkey
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Turkey" title="Cinema of Turkey">
        Cinema of Turkey
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TRT_World_logosu.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="271" data-file-width="1920" height="31" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/TRT_World_logosu.png/220px-TRT_World_logosu.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/TRT_World_logosu.png/330px-TRT_World_logosu.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/TRT_World_logosu.png/440px-TRT_World_logosu.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TRT_World_logosu.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/TRT_World" title="TRT World">
          TRT World
         </a>
         is the international news platform of the
         <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">
          Turkish Radio and Television Corporation
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465">
          <a href="#cite_note-465">
           [463]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Hundreds of television channels, thousands of local and national radio stations, several dozen newspapers, a productive and profitable
       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Turkey" title="Cinema of Turkey">
        national cinema
       </a>
       and a rapid growth of
       <a href="/wiki/Broadband" title="Broadband">
        broadband
       </a>
       Internet use all make up a very vibrant media industry in Turkey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tesevmedya_466-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tesevmedya-466">
         [464]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2003 a total of 257 television stations and 1,100 radio stations were licensed to operate, and others operated without licenses. Of those licensed, 16 television and 36 radio stations reached national audiences.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_467-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-cp-467">
         [465]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The majority of the audiences are shared among public broadcaster
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">
        TRT
       </a>
       and the network-style channels such as
       <a href="/wiki/Kanal_D" title="Kanal D">
        Kanal D
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Show_TV" title="Show TV">
        Show TV
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/ATV_(Turkey)" title="ATV (Turkey)">
        ATV
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Star_TV_(Turkey)" title="Star TV (Turkey)">
        Star TV
       </a>
       . The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Broadcast_media" title="Broadcast media">
        broadcast media
       </a>
       have a very high penetration as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satellite_dishes" title="Satellite dishes">
        satellite dishes
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cable_television" title="Cable television">
        cable
       </a>
       systems are widely available.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_467-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-cp-467">
         [465]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RT%C3%9CK" title="RTÜK">
        Radio and Television Supreme Council (RTÜK)
       </a>
       is the government body overseeing the broadcast media.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_467-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-cp-467">
         [465]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By circulation, the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Turkey" title="List of newspapers in Turkey">
        most popular newspapers
       </a>
       are
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Posta_(newspaper)" title="Posta (newspaper)">
         Posta
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/H%C3%BCrriyet" title="Hürriyet">
         Hürriyet
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/S%C3%B6zc%C3%BC" title="Sözcü">
         Sözcü
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Sabah_(newspaper)" title="Sabah (newspaper)">
         Sabah
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Habert%C3%BCrk" title="Habertürk">
         Habertürk
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468">
        <a href="#cite_note-468">
         [466]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nuribilgeceylan.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="288" data-file-width="250" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Nuribilgeceylan.jpg/170px-Nuribilgeceylan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1a/Nuribilgeceylan.jpg 1.5x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nuribilgeceylan.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan" title="Nuri Bilge Ceylan">
          Nuri Bilge Ceylan
         </a>
         , Turkish film director, photographer and screenwriter who won the
         <a href="/wiki/2014_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="2014 Cannes Film Festival">
          2014
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">
          Palme d'Or
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_television_drama" title="Turkish television drama">
        Turkish television dramas
       </a>
       are increasingly becoming popular beyond Turkey's borders and are among the country's most vital exports, both in terms of profit and public relations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469">
        <a href="#cite_note-469">
         [467]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After sweeping the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">
        Middle East
       </a>
       's television market over the past decade, Turkish shows have aired in more than a dozen
       <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">
        South
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">
        Central American
       </a>
       countries in 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470">
        <a href="#cite_note-470">
         [468]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Turkey is today the worlds second largest exporter of television series.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471">
        <a href="#cite_note-471">
         [469]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ye%C5%9Fil%C3%A7am" title="Yeşilçam">
         Yeşilçam
        </a>
       </i>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Sobriquet" title="Sobriquet">
        sobriquet
       </a>
       that refers to the Turkish film art and industry. The first movie exhibited in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman Empire
       </a>
       was the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lumiere_Brothers" title="Lumiere Brothers">
        Lumiere Brothers
       </a>
       ' 1895 film,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/L%27Arriv%C3%A9e_d%27un_train_en_gare_de_La_Ciotat" title="L'Arrivée d'un train en gare de La Ciotat">
         L'Arrivée d'un train en gare de La Ciotat
        </a>
       </i>
       , which was shown in
       <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">
        Istanbul
       </a>
       in 1896. The first Turkish-made film was a documentary entitled
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Ayastefanos%27taki_Rus_Abidesinin_Y%C4%B1k%C4%B1l%C4%B1%C5%9F%C4%B1" title="Ayastefanos'taki Rus Abidesinin Yıkılışı">
         Ayastefanos'taki Rus Abidesinin Yıkılışı
        </a>
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        Demolition of the Russian Monument at
        <a href="/wiki/Ye%C5%9Filk%C3%B6y" title="Yeşilköy">
         San Stefano
        </a>
       </i>
       ), directed by
       <a href="/wiki/Fuat_Uzk%C4%B1nay" title="Fuat Uzkınay">
        Fuat Uzkınay
       </a>
       and completed in 1914. The first narrative film,
       <a href="/wiki/Sedat_Simavi" title="Sedat Simavi">
        Sedat Simavi
       </a>
       's
       <i>
        The Spy
       </i>
       , was released in 1917. Turkey's first sound film was shown in 1931. Turkish directors like
       <a href="/wiki/Ferzan_%C3%96zpetek" title="Ferzan Özpetek">
        Ferzan Özpetek
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan" title="Nuri Bilge Ceylan">
        Nuri Bilge Ceylan
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1lmaz_G%C3%BCney" title="Yılmaz Güney">
        Yılmaz Güney
       </a>
       won numerous international awards such as
       <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">
        Palme d'Or
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bear" title="Golden Bear">
        Golden Bear
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org5_472-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org5-472">
         [470]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Despite legal provisions,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Turkey" title="Media freedom in Turkey">
        media freedom in Turkey
       </a>
       has steadily deteriorated from 2010 onwards, with a precipitous decline following the attempted coup in July 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473">
        <a href="#cite_note-473">
         [471]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of 2017, at least 81
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_arrested_journalists_in_Turkey" title="List of arrested journalists in Turkey">
        journalists are imprisoned
       </a>
       in Turkey. Ranking 1st in the world, all of them facing anti-state charges, in the wake of an unprecedented crackdown that has included the shuttering of more than 100 news outlets.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cpj.org1_156-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-cpj.org1-156">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
        Freedom House
       </a>
       lists Turkey's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Turkey" title="Media freedom in Turkey">
        media
       </a>
       as
       <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_Press_(report)" title="Freedom of the Press (report)">
        <i>
         not free
        </i>
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_159-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-159">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The media crackdowns also extend to
       <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship" title="Internet censorship">
        Internet censorship
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/2017_block_of_Wikipedia_in_Turkey" title="2017 block of Wikipedia in Turkey">
        Wikipedia getting blocked since April 2017
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474">
        <a href="#cite_note-474">
         [472]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475">
        <a href="#cite_note-475">
         [473]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
        See also
       </span>
      </h2>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Turkey-related_articles" title="Index of Turkey-related articles">
         Index of Turkey-related articles
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Turkey" title="Outline of Turkey">
         Outline of Turkey
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: upper-roman;">
       <ol class="references">
        <li id="cite_note-two-26">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-two_26-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          the government of Turkey
          <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Genocide_denial" title="Armenian Genocide denial">
           denies
          </a>
          that there was an act of ethnic cleansing.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-five-360">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-five_360-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          However, these are based on the existing religion information written on every citizen's national id card, that is automatically passed on from the parents to every newborn, and do not necessarily represent individual choice. Furthermore, anyone who was not officially registered as Christian or Jewish by the time of the foundation of the republic, was automatically recorded as Muslim, and this label has been passed down to new generations. Therefore, the official number of Muslims also include people with no religion; converted from Islam to a different religion than Islam; and anyone who is of a different religion than their parents, but hasn't applied for a change of their individual records.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blogs.lse.ac.uk1_359-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-blogs.lse.ac.uk1-359">
            [358]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ol>
      </div>

             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>

           </i>
          </a>

         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Population_of_Turkey-2">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_2-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.turkstat.gov.tr/Start.do;jsessionid=0vGcYT0TYz2h2GcPNtHNM49KbhgCGYCLLYGN2XtmVNK6xgLYl21g!-1359253179" rel="nofollow">

           </a>

           <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Statistical_Institute" title="Turkish Statistical Institute">
            Turkish Statistical Institute
           </a>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             2 February
            </span>
            2017
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Population+by+Years%2C+Age+Group+and+Sex%2C+Census+of+Population+%E2%80%93+T%C3%9C%C4%B0K+%2831+December+2016%29&amp;rft.pub=Turkish+Statistical+Institute&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.turkstat.gov.tr%2FStart.do%3Bjsessionid%3D0vGcYT0TYz2h2GcPNtHNM49KbhgCGYCLLYGN2XtmVNK6xgLYl21g%21-1359253179&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">

        <li id="cite_note-9">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-9">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Zdanowski, Jerzy (2014).
           <i>
            Middle Eastern Societies in the 20th Century
           </i>
           . Cambridge Scholars Publishing. p. 11.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1443869591" title="Special:BookSources/978-1443869591">
            978-1443869591
           </a>
           .
           <q>
            The Republic of Turkey lies on two continents. Approximately 97% of it is in Asia, in the geographical regions known as Asia Minor and the Armenian Upland. The remaining 3% of Turkey is in Europe, on the Balkan Peninsula.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Middle+Eastern+Societies+in+the+20th+Century&amp;rft.pages=11&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+Scholars+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1443869591&amp;rft.aulast=Zdanowski&amp;rft.aufirst=Jerzy&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-NatlGeoAtlas2-10">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-NatlGeoAtlas2_10-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           <i>
            National Geographic Atlas of the World
           </i>
           (7th ed.). Washington, D.C.:
           <a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_Society" title="National Geographic Society">
            National Geographic
           </a>
           . 1999.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-7922-7528-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-7922-7528-4">
            0-7922-7528-4
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=National+Geographic+Atlas+of+the+World&amp;rft.place=Washington%2C+D.C.&amp;rft.edition=7th&amp;rft.pub=National+Geographic&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.isbn=0-7922-7528-4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          "Europe" (pp. 68–69); "Asia" (pp. 90–91): "A commonly accepted division between Asia and Europe ... is formed by the Ural Mountains, Ural River, Caspian Sea, Caucasus Mountains, and the Black Sea with its outlets, the Bosporus and Dardanelles."
         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-Roopnarine2015-13">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Roopnarine2015_13-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Jaipaul L. Roopnarine (26 August 2015).
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ffpPCgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA328" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Fathers Across Cultures: The Importance, Roles, and Diverse Practices of Dads: The Importance, Roles, and Diverse Practices of Dads
            </i>
           </a>
           . ABC-CLIO. p. 328.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4408-3232-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4408-3232-1">
            978-1-4408-3232-1
           </a>
           .
           <q>
            Kurds are the largest ethnic minority group (about 20%), and Armenians, Greeks, Sephardic Jews,...
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Fathers+Across+Cultures%3A+The+Importance%2C+Roles%2C+and+Diverse+Practices+of+Dads%3A+The+Importance%2C+Roles%2C+and+Diverse+Practices+of+Dads&amp;rft.pages=328&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2015-08-26&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4408-3232-1&amp;rft.au=Jaipaul+L.+Roopnarine&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DffpPCgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA328&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-MedinaHepner2013-14">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-MedinaHepner2013_14-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Richard M. Medina; George F. Hepner (4 April 2013).
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=abbMBQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA113" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             The Geography of International Terrorism: An Introduction to Spaces and Places of Violent Non-State Groups
            </i>
           </a>
           . CRC Press. p. 113.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4398-8688-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4398-8688-5">
            978-1-4398-8688-5
           </a>
           .
           <q>
            Turkey has numerous non-Turkish ethnic groups of which the Kurds are the largest, comprising approximately 20% of the population.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Geography+of+International+Terrorism%3A+An+Introduction+to+Spaces+and+Places+of+Violent+Non-State+Groups&amp;rft.pages=113&amp;rft.pub=CRC+Press&amp;rft.date=2013-04-04&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4398-8688-5&amp;rft.au=Richard+M.+Medina&amp;rft.au=George+F.+Hepner&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DabbMBQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA113&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-15">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-15">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>

         <span class="reference-text">

           </a>

        <li id="cite_note-17">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-17">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Stiner, Mary C.; Kuhn, Steven L.; Güleç, Erksin.
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/236037711_Early_Upper_Paleolithic_shell_beads_at_Ucagizli_Cave_I_Turkey_Technology_and_the_socioeconomic_context_of_ornament_life-histories" rel="nofollow">
            "Early Upper Paleolithic shell beads at Üçağızlı Cave I (Turkey): Technology and the socioeconomic context of ornament life-histories"

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070515022203/http://www.abgs.gov.tr/en/tur-eu_relations_dosyalar/chronology.htm" rel="nofollow">
            "Chronology of Turkey-EU relations"
           </a>
           . Turkish Secretariat of European Union Affairs. Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.abgs.gov.tr/en/tur-eu_relations_dosyalar/chronology.htm" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           on 15 May 2007
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             30 October
            </span>

        <li id="cite_note-TurkEtymology2-41">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

           </a>

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Harper, Douglas.
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.etymonline.com/?term=Turk" rel="nofollow">
            "Turk"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Online_Etymology_Dictionary" title="Online Etymology Dictionary">
             Online Etymology Dictionary
            </a>
           </i>

            . Retrieved

            </span>
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Online+Etymology+Dictionary&amp;rft.atitle=Turk&amp;rft.au=Harper%2C+Douglas&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.etymonline.com%2F%3Fterm%3DTurk&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-42">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-42">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Jenkins, Romilly James Heald (1967).
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3al15wpFWiMC&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;dq=inauthor:%22Constantine+VII+Porphyrogenitus+(Emperor+of+the+East)%22&amp;hl=tr&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=-eYdUs3tHcSihgfG6YHIAg&amp;ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             De Administrando Imperio by Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus
            </i>
           </a>
           . Corpus fontium historiae Byzantinae (New, revised ed.). Washington, D.C.: Dumbarton Oaks Center for Byzantine Studies. p. 65.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-88402-021-5" title="Special:BookSources/0-88402-021-5">
            0-88402-021-5
           </a>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             28 August
            </span>
            2013
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=De+Administrando+Imperio+by+Constantine+VII+Porphyrogenitus&amp;rft.place=Washington%2C+D.C.&amp;rft.series=Corpus+fontium+historiae+Byzantinae&amp;rft.pages=65&amp;rft.edition=New%2C+revised&amp;rft.pub=Dumbarton+Oaks+Center+for+Byzantine+Studies&amp;rft.date=1967&amp;rft.isbn=0-88402-021-5&amp;rft.aulast=Jenkins&amp;rft.aufirst=Romilly+James+Heald&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3al15wpFWiMC%26printsec%3Dfrontcover%26dq%3Dinauthor%3A%2522Constantine%2BVII%2BPorphyrogenitus%2B%28Emperor%2Bof%2Bthe%2BEast%29%2522%26hl%3Dtr%26sa%3DX%26ei%3D-eYdUs3tHcSihgfG6YHIAg%26ved%3D0CC4Q6AEwAA%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          According to Constantine Porphyrogenitus, writing in his
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/De_Administrando_Imperio" title="De Administrando Imperio">
            De Administrando Imperio
           </a>
          </i>
          (ca. 950 AD)
          <i>
           "Patzinakia, the
           <a href="/wiki/Pechenegs" title="Pechenegs">
            Pecheneg realm
           </a>
           , stretches west as far as the
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siret_River" title="Siret River">
            Siret River
           </a>
           (or even the
           <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">
            Eastern Carpathian Mountains
           </a>
           ), and is four days distant from Tourkia (i.e. Hungary)."
          </i>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-PrinzingSalamon19992-43">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-PrinzingSalamon19992_43-0">

           </a>
          </b>
         </span>

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=hFc4mwsHZ7IC&amp;pg=PA3" rel="nofollow">

           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">

           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-60520-134-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-60520-134-4">

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=History+of+the+Mongols+from+the+9th+to+the+19th+Century%3A+The+So-called+Tartars+of+Russia+and+Central+Asia&amp;rft.pages=3&amp;rft.pub=Cosimo%2C+Inc.&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-60520-134-4&amp;rft.au=Henry+Hoyle+Howorth&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DhFc4mwsHZ7IC%26pg%3DPA3&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">
           <span style="display:none;">

        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-45">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-45">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a href="/wiki/%C3%96zhan_%C3%96zt%C3%BCrk" title="Özhan Öztürk">
            Öztürk, Özhan
           </a>
           (2011).
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120915062836/http://www.karalahana.com/makaleler/kitap/pontus-antik-cagdan-gunumuze-karadeniz-etnik-siyasi-tarihi.htm" rel="nofollow">
            "Pontus: Antik Çağ'dan Günümüze Karadeniz'in Etnik ve Siyasi Tarihi"
           </a>
           . Ankara: Genesis Yayınları. p. 364. Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.karalahana.com/makaleler/kitap/pontus-antik-cagdan-gunumuze-karadeniz-etnik-siyasi-tarihi.htm" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           on 15 September 2012.
           <q>
            ... Greek term Tourkoi first used for the Khazars in 568 AD. In addition in "De Administrando Imperio" Hungarians call Tourkoi too once known as Sabiroi ...
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Pontus%3A+Antik+%C3%87a%C4%9F%27dan+G%C3%BCn%C3%BCm%C3%BCze+Karadeniz%27in+Etnik+ve+Siyasi+Tarihi&amp;rft.place=Ankara&amp;rft.pages=364&amp;rft.pub=Genesis+Yay%C4%B1nlar%C4%B1&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.aulast=%C3%96zt%C3%BCrk&amp;rft.aufirst=%C3%96zhan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.karalahana.com%2Fmakaleler%2Fkitap%2Fpontus-antik-cagdan-gunumuze-karadeniz-etnik-siyasi-tarihi.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-ArchMag-46">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-ArchMag_46-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-ArchMag_46-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.archaeology.org/0811/abstracts/turkey.html" rel="nofollow">
            "The World's First Temple"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Archaeology magazine
           </i>
           . Nov–Dec 2008. p. 23.
          </cite>

         <span class="reference-text">

          <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=qDgsAQAAIAAJ&amp;q=seljuks+highly+persianised&amp;dq=seljuks+highly+persianised&amp;hl=nl&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0CCcQ6AEwAjgKahUKEwjLgILa343GAhXGDNsKHZyLAG0" rel="nofollow">
           "The Middle East For Dummies"
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0764554832" title="Special:BookSources/0764554832">

          </a>
          p 66
         </span>
        </li>

          <b>

            ^
           </a>
          </b>

         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Clogg, Richard (20 June 2002).
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=H5pyUIY4THYC" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             A Concise History of Greece
            </i>
           </a>
           . Cambridge University Press. p. 101.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-00479-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-00479-4">

           <span class="reference-accessdate">

             9 February
            </span>

           </span>
